Entry.1:
- Day of Embarkation

Left Liverpool 11.50 & arrSydney station at 5 to 1numerous haltsapparently without reason:Soon ascertained troopswere withdifficulty proceeding in single file - decidedtomarch in pairsby joining hands but owing to numerous halts abandoned scheme. At 2.20 I was still in eddy avenue. Here saw Ivy Ormsby & later Nina Kelly. Before passinginto GeorgeStsaw one whom I was glad to see & she walked in with me. All attempt to march in military formation having been abandoned We still wandered it was not even walking so dense& so insistent was the crowds. Everyone desiredto shake ones hand. say good byeIt seemed they were glad to get rid of us. To me it all seemed so much rotasthesepeople yesterday neither knew of nor cared for me & yet today overflowing with sympathy & well wishes. If they thought so much of the soldierelementthey might have demonstrated it to the men during the periodthey were staying in Sydney prior to their embarkation. On Brickfield Hillmet my mother & sister & walked with them on edge of crowd. Am afraid mum will break down so persuadeher to leave me & afterwards rejoin me at St Mary. Route of procession is Eddy Avenue Rawson Place George St Martin place Moore St Castlereagh St Hunter St MacquarieSt St MaryRdStJohns CrescenttoNo 1 Warburton.

At Queens place mater& sister found me & I said goodbye for last time & moved away quickly with a heart filled nigh to bursting as canbe well imagined - saw Mrs Crachersfriend. MetBenPrice who informed me that twomen one elderly was waiting for me suppose it to be Hawkins. At bottom also met Her& we marched together

towharf. After other parting this was indeed bitter. But she bore it bravely & we parted perhaps never to meet again even if I survive. At wharf crowd has closed in & there was no way. Forcedmy way in & found no one. Returned & directed troops to our standard&again met Her. This parting was more bitter and she almost broke down. But she is brave. See MCleamon& promise tobring her down but never return as reinforcement is almost ready & cannot get out. We move on wharf & finally on board. Pay starts& am in middle of it as ship moves away from wharf cannot get upon deck but cast a hurried glance thro a port hole but fail to seeher. Luckhas been given me on wharf. It was Hawkinswho sought me & he has given me a letter to Arthur Masonstrangehis wife isMissGraham of Greenwich if I remember rightly. Work israpid& continuousbutfinally all square about 9. & we found we rest in servicetill 11amnextmorning so rumour says.
Entry.2:
We up anchor at 6am & proceed out - cannot see anyone at Hy. Bl.but wave continuously. Sometimes I think I see a wave but am not sure. But continue waving.I am standingon Hurricane deck under boats I continue towave till we have passed Heads & after leaving pilotcontinue waving 
for
 till we are about 5 miles away & my arm is tired. Sea is like glass. We carry on for about 20 M & then turn south so away go our hopes of Panama. We keepland all day so Panamaseems farther away. No work today. There is a swell & everyone is sick.
Entry.3:
I am deck orderly officer today & have quite a busy time instructing an stowing hammock in.At 11am grand inspection by CO ship & OCtroops. Captain is careful about closing

port holes so this looks like heavy weather coming on. There is a good pitchingbut nothing to speak of. Ship is a good weather boat. On her previous voyage 12 men left her because they thought she was topheavy.This is untrue Her rolling powersonlast voyage more due to the fact that boat was in ballastAllotment in boat stationcame out today. I get a collapsible boat out on arrangement. - Speedis 11 ½today Price is our orderly he has been valet to an Indian Rajah & hotel waiter at Australia - some orderly eh! I am sitting at head table with Carmichael& Pearce opp. Major CrespinCO Troops, SMO & adjutant BorrodenThis is shortest day in year & it has passed somehow.
Entry.4:
(Sat)

Out of sight of land - supposed to have entered Bass Strait last night midnight. Thoughts returnof home & for a moment one thinks deeply but 
a wave 
spray breaking over deck & the cheers of the men who have not been wet by it change one thoughts whch are resumed only to be interrupted by some one making a complaint or asking information. Mole& myself divide duty between us. As is his day on duty today & I am off I will try& learn some German. The task does not seem very hopeful asone book says it is necessary to learn 10,000 words before one can hope to be fluent.
Entry.5:
Sun

Decide to go to C of E padre who has been an infantryman at front & stretcher bearer in BMC & has been once wounded. There were only 2 services Protestant & RC Gorrie took protestant as Prespadreis ill. Service is very impressive amid the waste of water - no land in sight. Hymns very appropriate. Our eyes fill with tears

when prayers for loved ones at home are offered up. We hear today that mail closes Tuesday to allow censor to finish it by Thursday. All officers are appointed Censor & Padres chief censors Such a job Inever desire againApart from prying into other peoples private affairs the amount of work and the tiresome nature of it is beyond belief.Germanhas now gone by board as some men have written as many as 42letters & postcards. There are only 150 men in unit but thank goodness each one does not write so many.
Entry.6:
Mon

Still censoring - sea is a longer swell & the ship is rolling more. Tonight there is a concert. I start to go & met the C of E padre & speak of censoring letters in French. Later in evening we met on deck & find a masonic bond thro speakingof Rasocrucians I see hisMasonic Bible & certificates & afterward return to censoring.
Entry.7:
I am ships orderly officer. - slidout of sight of land sea running a heavy swell beamsea. Make formal inspection of ship with "red men". We are travelingas a dark ship - no light at all being visible - passed a 4 masted steamer this afternoon - 
left
Boat stationpractised this afternoon. Bates goes to Hospital - spend night in cabin with German againbut go to sleep.

Censoringgives amusing episode

We areescortingtwo man of war

keepwellMum & ask dad to throw beer in though I dont suppose he will for me
Entry.8: Rain squalls all day - remained below - boatstationspractised in afternoon
Entry.9:
expected to reach land 2am yesterday still no landin sight. Very heavy sea during the night& in morning Molesworthclothes are wet though mine have escaped by sherluck This morning a heavy gale isblowing. white horses everywhere. Ship is punching her waythrow& they sayall decks even to promenade with heavy cloudsof spray - on either side of bows water displaced as she buries herself is lashed into a broad white way by wind. Land is visible every now & again through the showers. Occasionally a ray of sunshine addsbrilliance to the scene. I spend most of morning watching the sea. At
 dinner
luncheon I have smoke with Corre Varis& he lends me a book. While talking to him ship enters smooth water. at 7.45pm. We go up on deck & find ourselves in an open roadstead- very rough as westerly gales still raging. No sign of Albany visible We continue on & passin & thenceAlbany. We let go starboard anchor& as itfails to holdthe other one moor in mid stream. Areboard by Naval& militarypeopleHMC etc Albany is a quaint little town at the foot of a high 
high
hill with a black prominent cliff. Harbour is good&safe though on large size as windshave goodplay on water. We put ashore VD. Padres SMO YMCA& ACF & adjutant go ashore - no leave for remainder - but coalhulks & 1 water tank come alongside & we ship 450 tons of coal due to leave 8pm tomorrow. I have sent ashore 2 telegrams 1 home & 1 other. perhaps the post mark will give portat which we have arrived Have just stepped up on deck to see Albany by night Scene is very pretty with moon on water & lights in distance. Coalingis going on just over our heads is very noisy probably no sleep tonight. 4 gangs are at work each shifting 20 tons per hour. While coaling lasts no sleep is possible. In addition to coal hulks (one is called Kelat) on both sides we have a water tank unit heavygoing all night. Party onshore have not returned. YMCAis



NoteYMCA Sydney 100swent ashore

loaded with commissions over£100& hassent 450 telegrams back. When the shore party return it is over the coal & coal hulks. Met customs officer & he tells me vessel is to sail at 7 am tomorrow.
Entry.10:
Arise early- & try my usual warm saltwater plunge but warm water is off as we are in port. I hurriedly dress myself to go up & see land before ship sails. Weatheris very cold - a strong north wester is blowing.

The water is deep inside with good holding ground elsewhere the water is shallow& vergesto a bright green near shore - prominent basalt cliffs jut out especially on Melville. In many other parts white patches of sand resembling in many places chalkcliff. Ground is barren - no trees save one clump -practicallyno habitations save at township. I take some photos but expect no results. Have seen sun rise over land for perhaps the last time. very prettyrising 
oyt
 over headlands which rose in tiers & interspersed knolls. Now told that ship will not sail till 10. It must await train from Perth When train arrives it brings nothing for ship but as ship has waited it can go. Another example of general orders being forgotten by someone.

Still some delay but at noon we move off. Pass on starboard rock marked basalt. This is evidently volcanic & for most part is destitute of even grass which Passingdown we passed Michaelmas Is. resembling somewhatin shape & position Lion Island at Broken Bay. then Breaksea a long basalt rock covered in parts with a green carpet of moss or small shrub. Waves are atomised on cliff & thrown in white clouds along cliffs for considerable distances. In other parts beautiful cascades are formed one especially right beneathLighthouse. Flag at lighthouse blue ensign dipped three times to us & people wave.View ofSound withwarm sunplaying on our quarterfor first time & sparkling over waters is very pretty. Our last glimpses of Australia in spite of its barrennessis one of sparkling waters & white beaches. It takes 1/2 half from mooring to cross out passing out at 12.30. The sea is fairly rough & increases to galetoward night. The heaviest roll we have had so far. In cabin I was readingMoles cabin trunk knocks me off my feet & books fly at my head from all shelves In midst of my attempts to save some things from falling light goes out & all is confusion. I take refuge in saloon above. One officer sitting on a bench is hurled across saloon & cannons of another officers (also on ground) feet & comes back. Well for us it is that dinner is finished. Even at dinner time pears from one table were hurled at feet of people on other side of saloon & now it is worse. Difficult it is to write & at each instant one must pause to grip the table. Outside it is a dark ship & a darker night. It is impossible to see your hand or find where the door is. I turn & fall down companion ladder but luckily my hand strikes & catches rail otherwise I should not have been here tonight. The waves show faintly luminous. She is punching her way thro & every now & again shudders from stem to stern During the night sea increases & we have some very heavy rolls some being as much as 30o especially in saloon after tea. Penby does his famous slide & collides with Creighton& quartet practice a major roll
Entry.11:
Still rolling heavy - few have slept during night Captain Jackson tells us ship can do much better & that he expects fine weatherbut we

will get it very rough round cape as we will strike it in mid winter. One officer at this time of year did 70 miles per day. Sea is so rough that Capt takes off engines to allow me to draw their meals at galley Ships run so far for 24 hours has been 253 & there aboutslast 24 hours she has averaged 10 knots. The sea is not exactly rough but wind is almost a hurricane. Many of caps of waves wash over bow& are carried to promenade deck. Too rough this afternoon for usual boatstations. At dinner tonight OC announces a concert among the officers & Carmichael asks me to collect the artists& invite the sisters In midst CSM see me re VD space below & engages me till nearly 8 Igo in one nearbybunkin whichshe is lying down seasick &converse with this unknown sister in the dark just tocheer her up as she is too
 dark
sick to come to concert. I then go aloft to find captain &my word but I never knew it was blowing so hard. I find wireless room & knock & instantly lights go out & operator comes out. He shows me captain cabin but yell as loud as I can one can scarcely hear. Coming down & attempt to decidewhether to hang on & get wetor move forward & be blown away. Wind is hurricane speed. Impromptu concert is a great success. This afternoon I forgot to state Penly repeated his sliding act& covered Carmichael with tea. Carmichael goes below changes & he's down in about ¼hour ship ships a sea & flings it against Carmichael porthole which is not properly closed & thoroughly drenches him. I return him his book "L'amant de la petite Dubois" a french romance he had previously lent me.

N3 Sutton& Harod 
N5 Elliot& Parsons AMC
N4Kidd & Hawkins Major Griffiths
N6 Little G C & Uren Cap. McCutcheon
N7 Scanlon & Lea " Cochrane
N8 Little & Molesworth " Love
N9 Penly & Creighton " Meagher

 Capt O. Behram(Dental)

Sisters
I Lambert ThomasCurtain MacDonell Black Smith O'Donnell

Attached
Ellis NMCR Pearce HCF

Padres
Mangon RC Gorrie C of E Rankin Pres

After concert for first time I play draughts with Rankin then promenade the deck a risky performance on a dark ship in a rough sea &retire. At 1 I am awakened Molesworth has been been bombarded by flying missiles Everythingis adrift. Ship is doing very good at rolling. Cabin next door has 2 inches of water all over the floor & we take some of their goods into our cabin At 4.15 I am again awakened Molesworth trunkis rolling from one side of cabin to other & striking wooden partition of next cabin very forcibly every timeWe let it go & sleep. Molesworth cant sleep. Few on ship have slept.
Entry.12: (11)Eleventh day out. Truly ship has excelled herself at rolling. Captain has eased boat at 11 pm last night at 8 am this morning she is doing 4 knots & has done 160 mile in last 24 hrs. Nochurch parade today as weather is too rough I seize
Entry.13: gambling school in N 9. Go up on promenade deck before dinner & she does some beautiful rolls but she is so quick at recovering herself that I am never afraid. At dinner it is eat when you & holdon all the time. The water in reservoir has run over withroll& wet all my clothes. Trunks are now lashed up.
Entry.14: (12) Still veryheavy roll ship eased for breakfast. Drill commenced today but men are not yet steady. Much confusion exists as this is first parade. Very heavy rolling all night. Port engine stopped on account of a hot bearing - Rolls over her scuppers Majors Lecture.
Entry.15:
(13)

Ship has had very bad night & is eased up for breakfast - has in spite of yesterdays mishap & stoppages covered 273 miles - expect to reach Durban Monday week. Drill as usual - Concert at night N2Sudden lurch ends performance of band & ship -band & all officers catapultedinto one used jumble in corner.Fortunately no one is hurt though chairs are splintered into matchwood. Light is placed in wrong place & ship



officers close it down. Concert proceeds in dark but keep on meansare invisible - we proceedwith a torch Concert in dark is very weird - no light whatsoever & the phantom shapes on a rolling platform - the darkness lit now & then by bright points of cigarette ends The sides seem to be rolling aboutin space.The journeyfrom saloon toconcert was weird asship is dark & we had to hang on to each otherwhen ship allowed it & Molefelt his way. After concert continue German with interruption from Penly & find Behren can speak German.
Entry.16:
-18 Wed
.(14)

Night has been much quieter - Drill as usual this morning but as we are duty company only about 20 men on parade. Sea is calm & sun is warm we are evidently in Tropics - have lost touch with Perth wireless today. This afternoon sports of N2no parade. Chatsdiscovered in N2 & our guard washed & fumigated This afternooon sport and CSM writing out a general order. Ernstrepair books. Digweeddistributes citrate of magnesia. Tonight lecture by Major Griffiths on VD & the Empire & chatted with Padre Gorrie after. Before dinner yarned with Carmichael & consumed of his hospitality After dinner went up on deck & marched like kids arm in arm, in single file, &hip onhip on the dark deck If we lose touch we bump each. Break dish today.
Entry.17:
15 

I rise later & sleepier each morning. This morning the boy woke me & drank the coffee & slept again. After breakfast came the usual parade & after dinner owing to a case of measles All officers & the 7 sisters go into the inhalation room & thence to parade. Sea is calm now boat scarcely rolls - a strange occurrence. Days here in the tropics of the Indian are always the same. Dull grey morning which burst into 
silvery
bright sunshine(which turns the water silvery) about 11 & continues so till near 4 when the day turns grey again. This morning about 1 pm whilst at luncheon the day seemed very grey & the horizon closer & yet shadowy & ill defined

After a while I found we were passing through a bank of fog 
at.
This afternoon delivered a lecture to NCO. At dinner tonight we drink toast of allies as this is Independence Day & attempt to play Star Spangled Banner but no one knows it in any key whether whiskey or Yankee. Very good concert tonight but it lacks eeriness of other concerts as aconcealed light is used and sea is smooth.
Entry.18: (16) Sea still calm - rose 6.30 & visited men & then wentupon deck & gazed at ocean Everywhere the same grey sky - grey almost blue grey in someplaces in others just thinning to show lighter clouds Vessel crushingwaves into pretty blues - ascrestleadsagain into the main whilstalongside the foam of vanished & seething water lendsthe only bit of colourto the sceneThe monotonous & irresistibledrawing of the vessel thro the waste seems unnatural & I turn my eyes out to sea where only solitude & the restless sea exists & lose myself in them Then someone interrupts & I come back again. Capt tells us Llandovey Castle a hospital ship of Union Castle Line which he has builtsuperintended has been sunk. After breakfast parade physical training & in afternoon the same. Spent most of day censoring letters only to receive twice as many to be censored. Tonight at dinner Capt explained gross,net& registered tonnage & Simpson's rule also that yachts pay no dues or wharfage. After dinner lecture onGas& officers concert & then long talk with C of E padre.
Entry.19:
(17)

In the morning the parade as usual but the afternoon 
Dans le mater le
 is reserved for sports. Today it is boxing & there is some good sport. I and the officers are up on the boat deck & the men everywhere. One chap up a rope when told to come down lets go & gracefully slides down. Boat rolls & 100 men fall over. One is hurt I think. Sgt gets so excited that he yells directions which cannot be heard below

& nearly falls overboard. Wind is very cold at night 8pm we organise a meeting of Masons on board. We turned to number of 27 
30
expelling nurses from saloon. I am nominated SW. We decide hold similar meeting every week., to visit lodge at every port, to help each other, to have a dinner on board & to print a souvenir at Durban meeting disperses at 9.30 as men are waiting to sleep in saloon.
Entry.20:
(18)

Church service as usual. Glorious day - no sea Toward end of service sun disappears & the wind is cold. Letters are rolling in again & I pass all day censoring or sleeping only to find that at 7pm I am presented with about 500 extra letters the result of the days work by the men. In future I think I must find work for them.
Entry.21: (19)Sleepier than usual this morning. Usual routine breakfast parade - use medicine ball for first time. Parade at 2 pm ocuppy¼ usual space & CO is annoyed because his game of quoits is disturbed. Tonight Carmichaels lecture on Paschendale 1st engagement5,000 prisoners then 8 days rest & slaughter of us. Impromptu concert. As I am ships orderly officer make round of ship after lights out . Ship is like a rock now. Distance 2326 M to Durban.
Entry.22:
(20) nosea - ship has forgottenevenhow to roll. Am orderly officer ship & rise early - shower- a par boiled ballas there is no cold water. Ship inspection means visit to AftGun Deck which is used as a isolation hospital for measles. Deck has awning low & covered at side with tarpaulins - ideal airyhospital so long as 
ar
rain hangs off - men are in ships hanging cots - an excellent idea - it gives shelter from weather to a small extent. In aftenoon deliver lecture to N.C.O. & then turn in early as head is aching.
Entry.23:
(21) Off duty can lie in - have a good bath & then back to bed to cool - Before breakfast go up on deck. One of the finest mornings possible. trulywe are in tropics - the calm blue sea the suggestion of heat in a cool summer morning a picture fringe of cloud low on the sky. one instinctively turns to lookforthe for the broken fringe of surf which marks the coral reef but alasonly water - we are in mid Indian Ocean exactly1000 milessouth of Mauritius the Capt told me as he affectionately placed his arm aroundmy waist After breakfast make an inspection of men for purpose of finding men for duty while at Durban. In the afternoon we have our company sports wheelbarrow race - obstacle race (under seat, then roll a distance, then crawl then somersault, then run & vault over chair withdanger of splitting thru head)apple & treacle, knocking out of ring tug-of-war. Excitement ran high & men thoroughly enjoyed themselves Among the competition competition was keen. In obstacle race there was one man left so he did course alone with more cheering & encouragement than if he had a big field. & he responded & went as hard as he could just as if there were other competitors in the race. Owing to company being on guard I had to postpone sports as they were unfinished. Atnight in the troop deckswe had a cribbage & euchre tournament. Tonight we have had almost a riot in the mess as one of the ships wireless men has been carpeted for smoking in the saloon & has objected to others doing same thing. Consequently all military officers are requested to refrain from smoking till 9.30 pm. OC is furious. At dinner we arrange to leave as a body when Capt. rises & leave the ships officers the saloon. Action is unanimous & itwas difficult for me as I had to stop CO from leaving before skipper. Tonight I delivered a lecture to the officers re Hygieneships officers were absent. Also padres owing to a concert in B-deck So much the better I thought. After lecture I was bombarded with

questions but successfully fenced or answered them.

11-7-18 (Thurs)
 (22)

Usual routine - boil in bath - 645 return to bed - rise again 8.10 - shore - go on deck at 8.25 - five minutes an & then breakfast. Parade at 9.15am. Afternoon pay of£1 to each man desiring it. ie 1/- per day calculated to nearest 10/- Paybooks have to be signed in 2 places acquisitionsroll by men & paybookby me. I am not touching my pay as yet. There is£10 for me, menonly touch£2.10.0 during voyage. Meals are touchy at king table each officer excuses himself & retires as soon as possible. It is the smoking trouble still rankling. At dinner all leave in a body again. All day long have utilised Bartlet Taylor Bate & Blackett (a cousin of Blackett the barrister) all ex officers to do censoring in my cabin. Mail has closed today at midday for the men. Tonight as I write
thars
 this officers &nursesare coming back from concert & are amusing themselves talking in gibberish imitating the nigger stewards but which is laughable all the same. Theyhave been singing just now. None of them has the least conception of music. The exhibition was veryfunny particularly as in event of a pause the words of another song were sung in rapidlywith wonderful results. I am sitting alone aloof from others & nurses- writing this & some letter home presently. A solitary man alone with his thoughts not caring for the thoughts of others or desiring to share them. The majority of officers here are the men who previously were Staff Sergeant Majors & for the most part they are not particularly well bred & their manner of eating at table is rather nauseating to anyone with refinement. I prefer my own thoughtsto their company. Molesworth is a boy beside me
n
& between his thoughts & mine there is all the breadth of an educated man & a schoolboy.

12-7-18 Frid
 (28)

Usual routine. Sea is still calm & the sky the

same Indian or rather semi tropical morning that I have described before. Deck officer today Molesworth is now permanently detached for the ceremonial guard & thus free. Little time to myself to-day. This afternoon usual routine. Molesworthis preparing his lecture for to-night - Dinner & after that Molesworth's lecture. Then the usual Friday night concert & topical song - a versesetting out the events of the week & considering any officer.

13-7-18 Sat
 (23) Parade as usual - at 2pm boxing tournament continued. weak exhibition - fought on starboard side aft well deck - Muldon (13.5) has a byebut puts up an exhibition spar. Taps several times successively - takes hits on jaw & shows very clever footwork. At night continue the good work of writing home - hope letters give more pleasure at home than it gives me to write them. We yarn with padre Rankin.

14-7-18 Sun
 (24)

Have waiting till midnight to seeday in & immediately commenced a letter. Tho Sunday refuse to go to church & spend day in cabin in communion with her Finish a letter to her & wonder what she does, & does she remember this day of days. In afternoon pass with Sainton. He has been 4th mate of a ship & was on La France & GerardDusquesneas gunner. His leg was broken at Sydney & sent to Georges Head Hospital. When well his ship has sailed & he is ordered to join up at Noumea on 1 days notice. He asks permission to join up with AIF which is granted. He tells me of Marie Ducesnehis one time fiancee who has called his lack Littleshe knows him who has enlisted with a defective heart. Before this I have avoided him because memories would 
have
been too strong but today I welcome him a voice which reminds & saddens. Thus passed this day of sweetest memory which saddens while it inspired. At mess we drank the health ofFrance & band played Marseillaise whilst we stood to attention. Write to Hawkins & McDougall this time. Censorship is still going on. 

15-7-18
 (Mon) 25

Have been expecting to reach land all day. Sight it at 1 pm Day is clear but course of boat peculiar she goes due North & then in a circle. The day is very clear & warm & sea smooth. As we wait for pilot we see large tug towing a whaler & have to wait for next tug. There are 3tugsin this port supposed to be the three most powerful in world as breakwater is narrow& agale would have powerful effect on a sailing ship The tugs are bigger than old north coaster with twin screws - flying bridges etc with one or two yellow funnels. Single funnel is Harry Escombe & another is Richard Hill. It was the latter which met us . All hands go to boat stations.All troops had previously gone to one side & her rudder was hard over & the list was so pronounced that Capt was scared. The port is as per map. Water evennear wharf is shallow except where dredged. Dredges here are a powerful fleet (Nautilus, Cetusetc). We berth near breakwater heading as for sea. Men now start throwing coins to natives to see the fight that occurs for each penny. Some pennies have been heated. The natives are like gibbering monkeys. The demand for money is right hand thrown from left shoulder to side. then both palms turned up hollowed. My post during entrance is upon ladder. Price is near at hand. When alongside the sionquay like noumea with large sheds along quay & between sheds & water the railway line gauge 3‘6". When gangway off. 
Staff
civilmilitary & naval officers to number of about 40 board vessel. No quarantine. Whilst waiting for this watch natives dressed in multitudes of rags on wharf begging & scrambling. Miss Ellen MCampbell sister of Dr Campbell is alongside in a Ford car (the inevitable Ford) & passes oranges, signals greeting etc. Two well dressed niggers escorted by a wild object in rags who makes room for them. Leave is granted tonight & at 6 pm we all fall in on wharf & march to Town Hall & are dismissed. NCis exceptionally steady. We are then dismissed to fall in at 10 pm. March 40 minutes. Carmichael in charge of parade dismissesit with officers in rank & owes drinks. He collects available officers & goes to Royal Hotel (see photos). Refusalto give drinks save with

meals & Carm. busses off to send cables which are not sent. Some of officers then proceed to Durban Club. (A magnificent mansion used in Boer War as HQ & enlarged by Govt. still£28,000 in debt.) On the Marine Esplanade. We make ourselves honorary members by signing a book & buy books of coupons (10/- & 5/-) to purchase articles. Drinks are obtained & we set out to dine. Urenwanting oyster saloon. Party was Scanlon Little, Harrod Urenmyself & Scotson. At Club one man makes himself our host for the whole of one shout. Party loses Scanlon & Little & proceeds to Grosvenor. Place is almost empty & we go into smaller room. Onetable a colonel & staff captain, at another 1 officer & girl, another thereCSM & girl etc. Urenmethod of eating disgustsme & I have to regard ceiling intently. Drinks are unobtainable here as elsewhere after 8 pm even with meals. We leave & go out only to be assailed by rickshaboys. These are zulus (see photos) who earn large money, retire to hills, buy wines, drink,leave off exercise contract a heart trouble &die. Usual life is said to be 3 to 4years. We take a tram to Beach (Marine Parade) a beach with chairs,walk, abundance of side shows & catch pennies like Glenelg - lose Harrod & Uren.Scotson & I decide to walk back purchasing post cards on route. Fall in at 10 pm & march back to boat. When on board tearing & crashing sounds forwards &boat 
twis
rollsslowly but continuously to 
port
starboardAll make sure she is capsizing. I decide to order troops to port side to counterbalance weight but thinking everyone else may go funky & do same order them to stand fast. List ceases but is still considerable & remains like that for night. Starboard tanks only had been filled while port boilers emptied & the boat was heldupright by springs. The weight of troops was sufficient to upset balance & springs broke or tore up the iron attachments& over she went.

16-7-18 (Tues)
 26

I am detailedas thedaypicquetas Molesworth was on last night. I report at 9 am to APM. Capt Smith (staff colour is blue here as Dutch object to red) who is not there. W.O gives me a guide toPolice Court & we

find a large room set aside for purpose. I return to APM who does not want or expect me till 2 pm & in no case wants patrolsout byday picquet. We are merely a reserve. I arrangeshifts - allow balance to go on leave for fixed periods. Digweed is here. My H.Q is Durban Club or Royal Hotel but I must not wander elsewhere. In court is a long queue of ricksha boys re registering & near entrance we pass a lightly clad, slight native with headdress 2 ft long. This is her hair bound up with string & taking about 7/10 months to do up. I go to Royal for morning tea but find no one to talk to or interest me. I then go to Museum in Town Hall buildings. Collection is small contained in 2 large rooms but several fine specimens of large animals, eg.hartebeeste,eland,
gazelle
deerwildebeeste & lions while the evolution horse from fox size to present size by jawbones & hoof (once 5 toes) is illustrated. Also an excellent piece of colouration - a bird on nest impossible to detect at first sight. Also difference between male & female insects. There is also a Japanese land crab. Body about 1 foot diameter legs about 5 to 6 ft long & 2 ins thick. Claws as bigas my hand. side legs about 2 ftlong. There is also a cococraba pigmy alongside this animal. From Museum I mount to Art Gallery on next floor. This again is small but contain (1) a dying tigers head inverted by Sir W Landseer (2) a landscape with shore in whites & greys by Leader (3)Pursuit of Pleasure. A woman naked with figure of Medici & alluring face is pursued by a crowd of all ranks - women as beautiful as herself are trodden underneath by crowd. Flesh of women seems natural. How I do not know It is smoother than varnished oil. (4) Many excellent copies of Italian masters GiottoDa Vinci, (including one of Mona Lisa) & Titians (Last Supper) From gallery returned to piquet & thence to Durban Club for lunch. Lunch is not as good as I would expect from such a wealthy Club with native labour in fact University Club is equally as good. A naval officer in civilian attire lunches next to me & as usual asks impression Ipoint out the absence of girls or rather abundance of men & apparently strike a sore point as S.A men do not enlist readily. Sedition is rife & in fact very little would cause a warA plot today at Pretoria to seize members of Govt has just been thwarted

I speak of the extraordinary thickankles of the girls here & suspect that it is a relic of their Dutch extraction He tells me of a master who in recent years sailed his ship thru breakwater. He was fined£100 as if he had stranded the whole harbour might have silted up. The fine was remitted afterwards by public petition. This afternoon I intended to go to Zoo but wait for APM to go to tea. I stand outside station & met Molesworth & SMO who inform me ship may sail tomorrow. OC & adjutant join party & all take ricksha for beach. I thinkset out to search for MasonicHall & find 
i
that there is ameeting tonight; Wed Installation SC Thur Royal Arch SC working Mark Frid. Grand lodge SC Sat Installation 3pm & dance 8 pm. On way back a soldier & mason intrduces me to his cousin McIvorwhom I take over to Digweedwho is out. Digweed returns with Brewster & ( McIvor returns about 6pm.) We decide to form a party & go tonight. I set off now 4pm for afternoon tea at resort of the beautiful of Durban The Model Dairy(kept by one Baynes) On way meet Penly & buy a butterknife 10/6for mater & Ruffbox for Mollie (7/6) with Durban coat of arms thereon & then Penly refusesto tea & I teawith cold drinks alas without the beautiful but many staff officer & a live Bg general Creighton relieves me & I go to Royal met Pearce (a surly cub with unlimited cash going across to represent ACF but will soon be returned on arrival as useless) I walk around town for a while. Finally I leave him & go to dine at Lounge. After waiting 3/4 hour I go out without being served. Try Royal & find Pearce OC Troops & adjutant joins us. I have mixed grill (1/9) not much chop sausages 2 in long & chop invisible. I leave here for Masonic Lodge Ceremony is IC Salute is different. It is installation 1) W.O. Roberts. Opens in 10receive visitors - Installing master appoints his officers - Presentation of W M elect - D ofC recites ancient charges - B.B retire. Conclave of PM. BB return WM proclaimed in S then W then E - Presentation of Maul collar, jewel, USL Book of Constitution & Byelaws & Warrant of Lodge. WM saluted by Lodge. Investiture of Officers & address to them. Collection in aid of Benevolent fund from all & closes. Menu Fish poultry cold meats & saladscold pie fruit sweets, cheese, fruit. Toasts(1) King (2)- the 4 const. (3) Prov. GM & officers IC (4) absent BB (5) Dist GMN Natal EC SC & visitors (6) WM & new enlstofficers - The Tylers toast.

At intervalmet Capt Sutherland OC No 1 sector Congella Camp & Lt Sutherland Royal Scots. Whisky is abundant especially during the interval. Grand lodge does not make a statement in Lodge. Door is actually locked. I wear Green SC apron edged with Gordon tartan &green yellow crossings. blueband 2 black lines ground green blue band 2 double black

We all return home in rickshas & go on board.

We
Entry.24:
27

Parade at 9 am & march via Marine Esplanade to Park. Leave No 2 & Molesworth to clean up & move off N 8in rear. They march well & like soldiers in fact are the only soldiers in column. Near beach the old guard join having marched there direct under Sgt Davidson (Of LIsmore). Column proceeds to Beach for swim. Municipal authorities place baths at our exclusive disposal till 2 pm. N 8 is last in but gets all the gifts of the folks. Pretty girls & ugly fat women are in abundance in the chairs (free) & motor cars are plentiful While troops are swimming we Penly Scotson & I have ice cream & tea & cakes (3/4) woman waiter cannot understand what is an ice creamsoda & brings first an ice cream then puts ice cream in soda & when asked to add flavouring brings a glass of raspberry & water. After swim troops are marched to rear of Beach. dismissed. I then wander on thro native quarter & outskirts of town to boat. Change into slacks as weather even tho this is winter is warm. Still coco palms are not fully grown & so I think there must be a small rainfall. I go to zoo & Mitchell Park meeting on tram Lee & Creighton (whom I soon drop as tastes dissimilar) I proceed via Musgrave St. Michell Park is a pretty little spot -thought it was botanicgardens at first trees overhang pleasant walks tho vegetation is not very varied.There is a tea room & tables on lawn also a tennis court in one corner. The zoo is within this park & is free to soldiers. The specimens are exceptionally good. The tiger is the largest I have seen & I waited ¼ hour to see it rise. The lion & lionesses are also magnificent

while the collection of Australian animals & birds is very good. I return to town & decide to go to Umgeni where the river & mountain scenery is good. The baboons come out on road & scamper away in
 thousands
 groupsas tram passes. on return some chap in tram advises me to dine Grosvenor but I go to Marine Hotel - a vast structure on Esplanade & the last word in hotels a/c Durban. Tariff here is Breakfast 3/- Lunch 3/- Dinner 4/6 Daily tariff 15/- Suites comprising Sitting room, Bedroom, Bathroom etc from 27/6 & for two persons 42/- per day. There is a new lounge, Palm Court & Private Ball Room. As no one is in dining room I start to make enquiries & find dinner is 7:30 As there was no one to ask I stopped an English Officer Lt. D. Ferraby
Entry.26: East Yorks now both in KAR. Ferraby ask if I have ordered table as otherwise I will possibly not be able to get one & invite me to share their table if their table can be substituted for a table of 3. They go for brush up & ships captain comes in & asked if I am of the OC party. Ferraby comes back & goes into Dining room & comes back & informs me that all is well & we go in to dine. They insist that I shall l be their guest. We talk of many mattersand they sharply criticise the table manners of some of the Aust. officers. After dinner they tell me they have an engagment but will be going to a dance at Royal after & send me along at once with their apologies. Here I meet Mrs Jack Phillips PO Box331 Johannesburg. A fine tall & beautiful woman who is giving dance. She introduces me to some girls. Here are many officers of KAR who sail Friday & other officer. As well as all the wealth & all the beauty (mostly Jewish) of theRand. Names are too difficult to remember save Berman who asks me to a harbour excursion to Island tomorrow at 2. Ferraby will give merendezvous during march thro street tomorrow. I promise to look up Capt. P. Hayes
Entry.27: Battalion (1917 Nov) & then Ricksha back to boat.
Entry.28:
(28)

Parade this morning via Esplanade. N 9 in rear under Creighton makes bad tail. Incident of Hawkins thence to Park where our team plays S. Africa. We score 100 & lose match by 20 runs only.Nowiseplays for them. Parade is reformed at 1.30 & dismissed. Hence no march thro city & I am stranded as I do not know arrangements for this afternoon. I go to Royal to see if I can find them Scotson accompanying me. Met Gorrie & decide to return with him to ship On way look into Town Hall which is not as big or as finished as ours. Here we meet Jan & Michel Chermasky & we go to book tickets after hearing them play. Then with Gorrie go to ship & change then we go to Botanical Gardens These are small like most other things here. There is no variety orsilence& palm & hot house are filled with ferns or young palms - no choice or rare plants. The place is artistically laid out but apparently is not yet finished as lower part is used as a tip The one point of beauty is a palm tree walk running at footof hill. Path is
 bot
 straight & level & here there are some borders & plants with perfume. We then walk along Bot.Garden road & catch tram to Tollgate & walk along to Mayville though it is too dark to see much thoughit would be beautiful in daylight One house on a hill standing back from road is fine effect. Then we return to Club & I met
 Pa
McCutcheon, Molesworth & Major Maxwell Lyte & dine with them. Lyte devotes much attention to me & talk turns on zoological subjects. Sample Dracenburg sherry & for a liquer Van der Hum. This is McCutcheon dinner, Major wine &my cigars (10deach) Conversation continues re animals. I ask re kraals& agree to see Major tomorrow re engage a car for visit to Drummonds (Valley of a 1000 Hills )£4-10-0 or Maritzburg£9-0-0 or Unkomaas£7-0-0 These are Cooks price & are for four persons. Car gets back by 5pm Starts about 9am

 (29)

Today is leave. Go up to Cook then to char alonethen to Major Lyte. He tells me Sunday is probably free for our trip to the Valley of a Thousand HIlls. We go to Belgrave Hotel. The barmaid is Lottie Little then to Base Commandant Office & after Major has taken me to last rank to F Kitchen 53 North St Telephone 2036 & arrange tentatively for Sunday. Thence to Raily a large building of redNGR has 4 platforms all trains for day are exhibited on indicators - turned down as train left. Railway are now consolidated in Dominion & are known as South African Railways. Thence to municipal markets - These are 3 long buildings running from street to street & abutting end to end. The first has meat, butter & egg - these are auctioned by sample & if bid is high enough the whole consignment is sold at thatprice. If price not high enough it is put up again. The native officials are always much in evidence. Next building is meat but mainly vegetables while third is grain & poultry. Meat here at auction sale at Municipal abattoirs at 11.30am
Entry.29:
Carcasses of beef 38/- max 20/- min av. 29/9 per 100lbs. Carcases of mutton 8½d max 2d min av.6d per lb. Carcases of pork 10d max 6½d min av.8½per lb. I then passed on to Indian market but being doubtful of my way asked the only white man I could see who said if I waited till he finished his conversation he would show me. He was Fred W Holmes ofHolmedene 55 Montpelier Rd Durban & an Inspector of Nuisance. The best man I could have found for it is his duty to visit kitchens &cafe's & the markets & he is about to commence a tour which he enlarges for my benefit. We pass by Mosque & enter a Kaffir restaurant consists of long tables covered with tinat far end is a counter. Tea is supplied free sugar & bread fora ration. In open square dishes 3' x3'x4". One of these is piled with a soup with lumps of meat & fat in it. 
These 
 The other contains a gravy. Both are kept hot by an oil lamp. Food must be visible if dished from kitchen native would not eat it. One on made "clinchies" a lump of fat or 

meat in a flour covering. Now flour is too dear. The proprietor seems to be a Greek. From here we pass to an Hindu or Indian restaurant. This is wealthier. Tables are covered with marbles. Often see a table with plenty of room & yet newcomer goes & sits in yard. This is because of a different caste sitting at the table. Food 
cons
consists of 3 courses served 1 big plate rice & 3 saucers 1 of ^white salad (onions)1 of soup (vegetable) &1 of stew& 1 spoon. With spoon alittle soup is put on a portion of rice & mixed with fingers & then eaten with fingers. Spoon only used to dish out. The kitchen resembles an ovalpicture. Open fireplace with great round marmites one large one is full to top with rice & is off fire. The others supply soup & stew. Outside in yard are the peelers & another open fireplace. In another small room is man making confectionery. Mealy is ground & sieved Then mixed with ingredients dipped in a cauldron of boiling syrup & then dried over fire. Confectionery contains an undue amount of sugar but looks tasty. Vegetables - even eschalots radishes etc are largely used. Pastry kitchen has modern stove. Red colouring at 20/- per ½ lb is largely used in place of eggs. On my way out I taste chilie bites a batters with pieces of eschalots & lots of pepper. Burning taste remains in mouth for a long time. Anything I desire to taste is given to me on account of my friends position. The whole place is very clean for a foreign race. From here we proceed towards markets. These are approached by a street which about 4 till 6 am is a market itself. It is cleaned up by council men of waste leaves etc at about 11 am. The sight is very animated & worth seeing. In this street saw a Hindu with many cases of oranges, mandarins ready for shipment. Holmes asks me if I have tasted a "naartjze" (pron. narchee). On which vendor opens a case of each kind & gives me ½ dozmandarins6 oranges 6naartjze which is a cross between orange & a mandarin.Skin is thinner than mandarin We next go into a yard where banana packing is in prgress. Each bunch is cut into a hand of 6 or 7 according to number on stem, placed in case end up &then top filled in with the dead leaves 

Here I see for first time the jack fruit tree. It resembles 
small tr
contracted marrow with rough exterior & grows on the main stem of tree & not on a branch. The interior resembles pommegrante . We now enter the market (native part).

A represents stalls having native work shields, sticks, books.Jewellery exhibited. In one of them a native is making theanklets & armlets we see on certain castes or tribes by binding silver wire round horse hair.B is a Zulu drinking garden. The liquor is supplied by council who regulate quantity of alcohol. When a fresh lot arrives a bell is rung & all natives at hand with a penny form a queue. They paymoney receive a ticket which they surrender at a stile & receives a pot of " utywala" or ijigi. No one can get a second helping without quitting & re-entering in his turn. I taste the drink it is thick & pink & has very sour taste. I amuse the Zulus by the faces I make when drinking. We then pass to C the dining tables. Food is great hunks of fat, liver, sweet meat or any other rejected part of animal. Mealie abounds & bread fills gaps. Also the greasy stew with lumps of fat - taro root, yams. See a Zulu woman with headdress & investigate it much to girls amusement. She has only a rough clotharound her shoulder & waist. Arms neck breast & legs exposed.Her head dress in about 2 ft long & took 10 to put up. The hair is wove in & plaited with strands of string or fibre. These girls are from a kraal on4 or 5 days leave granted by Govt & return at end of that time. Girl has a slight but well moulded figure. Then pass to snuff vendor & sample the snuff using a snuff spoon. It causes me to sneeze & old Zulu says it must be good. then visit the medicine men - herbalists - their initiate is mingled with superstitious ideas dislike amputation but cup much with end of a horn.Teeth are extracted bydigging it out with a spear or any sharp piece of iron. Medicines are made of decoctions of leaves, roots, without regard to size of dose. Often patient succumbs. Poultices 

of leaves or bark are used for sprains, sores etc. with good results. Pieces of fish, head of animals & skins of snakes, hyena, porcupine & iguana are also used. Horns are used for storing ingredients. Then visit butcher shop. This stock is all the offal of markets & heads - Every bit is utilised even if rotten. Then proceed to Hindu fish market. Big heap of heads of a large kind of fish. Then pass into HIndu market proper - fruit vegetables mainly though a little confectioneryStall or tables are close together & tended by a woman or young child. Hindu women if young could be pretty tho they disfigure themselves by putting big brooches throughtheir nose. I here again have right to taste whatever I desire. The girls are well developed women at 14 & are very pretty. There is every variety of fruit & vegetable & are of very good quality. We then visit a fakir or divination expert. He is seated squat legged - small box on which he burns a powder in front of him. ornamented with bead & sign of Vishuin white & red. His fingers nails are 4 to 6 inches long middle fingers being full 6 ins.Then visit Indian cemetery This is just an ordinary field no sigh of a grave yet. I am told that it is chock full of deal It is crossed by one narrow foot track. Then return to RC Cathedral called Emmanuel as there was no saint day on 25 Decthe day Natal was founded. Present Bishop is Bishop Lavelle who about 14 years broughtout station of Cross from France.These are carved out of stone & painted & are the finest sculpture in stone that I have seen. The pillar & arches of the nave are of imported Venetian marble The whole church is without colour & yet magnificent tho subdued The altar is however decoratedwith gold & pale blue. From here we go to Mosque. Shoes must be taken off before entry.The man washes his feet hands head ears & mouth. There are electric lights for night. He then mounts platfrom & go through purification prayer. Two kinds of bowing half down & on hands & knees.

Then one waits to enter mosque. Here whole place is carpeted. These carpets are divided into two squares &each square represents on place. All sit crosslegged. There are no women. Priest read a script & then delivers a lecture. Always a thinshrill voice chants some little pharse at odd intervals. At conclusion priest descendsfrom rostrum, lays aside his staff & prays congregation salaaming when he does. We proceed to buy a m'weter = cn' wahitu & my friend demands that it should begiven to me. I then go to another shop & my friend obtains some sea horse or sjambok also for nothing but pay 4/- for a 6/- mooencha (spelt umtya)I proceed to shield factory. The leather is washed, soaked & cleaned & then stretched out to dry. It is then slit & pieces of other coloured strips of hair threaded thro it &grip made for fingers not hands. In one room see two native Zulu women in from kraal with their characteristichead dress chatting with their workmen perhaps their brother. They are light hearted slim creatures evidently having a good time & happy as can be. They are seated on mats. In next room a native with only a waist cloth on is making mealy that is crushing the white corn. Near we see a native stoning hisfeet which by constant stoning have become white. This is custom & is no more efficacious thanwashing. Then superintendent making of a snuff spoon. He carves it & then covers it with sealing wax put on a hot knife. Whole is then fileduntil the carving becomes apparent & whole is polished. Foot is usually used as anvil or rest.The finished articule is 
made
 presented to me& demand for " ticky" which my friend tells me not to give. Holmes then finds a stick made of um-zim-beet (phon) Price is haggeled over by my friend in Zulu who beats price down to 2/6 & tells me to give 2/- rather a cheap stick. My friend here leaves me having invited me to his home tomorrow & informs me he is a Mason. He tells me that price of house here

are very dear. usually cost about£1000 Rent is 7£ per month. Allotments are 50' +130' & for this you pay£700 to£1000. I return to boat with my curios& then to Railway. Trains for Zululand (North Coast) & south coast - distance may be judged by times between stations.

Trains
 here carry 3 classes. The 3rd is reserved for natives & is very rough. The first is similar to our box compartments save no seat near lavatory but there is atable with folding sides in centre. This makes compartment wider thanours & gives a footrest.

Trip to Amanzimtotu. Caught train 2.45 left 3.7 accidentat Illovo. Chum up with a mason & another man who gives me his seat & we become intimate. The country is open with range of hills on coast from which train is never far away. Pass big sugar factory & wireless station with 3 masts - chemical works - Kynocksexplosive factory with each group about 2 miles apart & in each group all little building surrounded by embankmentsopen at the four corners. Each little hut occupied by 1 workman & a boy.Wheels revolve very slowly sometimes hardly moving. Arrived at A & friend asks me to drink & find the proprietor of cafe has been suspended & the line Inspector iscarrying on. The man ismy friends brother-in-law & has a Zulu who can speak English & show me a kraal. We mount to kraala lonely position sea on one quarter, & deep valley & plain on other ringed in with hills. Whole is screened with bush from view. On way met finishspecimen of woman I have seen. 5'10" or 6' tall with shapely limb & laughing face clad in mooencha (pron). Next meet headman named Mad de gazelle. He has only mooencha Hehas 4 wives each wive has a hut, a small one in rear for children & a storehouse& kraal for cattle in centre. Enter one hut. Wife without headdress & naked making kaffir beer. Sa ku bona is her greeting. Hut (seelater) The appearance of laced twigis brilliant black but is dry - youngsters have no dress & at very young age carry pickanninies. Women carrier wood on their head seem picturesqueMadwomen do all the work including ploughing. Men do nothing so I ask permission totake photo & he demands ticky Photos will probably be bad as light is no good. Return to station to catch 5.40 pm train. It leaves at 7.45 owing to accident. Go down to

Amanzimtoti River & stand on bridge. River is subject tosudden rise & only half course is at present filled. Scene is very pretty & calm Meet SSF Reed of 30 Payn St Maritzburg & engaged timbering on location nearby When train does arrive I get into a saloon car. All sides glass. There is electric light in car but is burning at a brightness sufficient to give a dim light. On arriving at Durban I go to concert but am already ¾ hour late but hear Mishel (our friend of other day) on violincello in Sumer night Sulzsky Serenade Herbert Arlequin C Cui

In street meet Capt. Smith APM & claim my supper of the other day. We coffee at Royal & as he leaves I slip along & say good bye to Miss Berman & Mrs Phillips & come home in Ricksha I posted the presents home today. (spoon & snuff box

Glimpses of Zululand at Stanger
Entry.30:
(30)

For stations see previous day.

Hut is round - made of wickerwork & covered with straw or grass The wickerwork is wattle (acacia mollissima) poles placed upright in circle 2 ft apart. Smaller twigs are interlaced between these 2 openingsleft 1 for window (not always there) & 1 for door 3' x 2'6" There is an inner circle of poles to support roof & fire is in centre of these The dome of roof is same wickerwork as sides & above this is placed bundles of straw till roof asumes shape of a dome. Zulu huts rarely have plastered walls like Basutos There is no chimney & rarely window On entering the master of house (umnumzana zana) occupies central position near fireplace. His women are on left (entering) & men on right had side of hut. On entering



utter salutation 'Sa ku bona" This means like see you. It is easy to see them when ones eyes are accustomed to gloom as all are stark naked except for beads & mooencha. Visitor remains silenttill master of house asks his business & conversation opens. On the left the side occupied by the women are a pile of wood, sleeping mats, wooden pillows, blankets, pots & various utensils a space exists alsoin some kraals for calves, kids & fowls, thoughthis is not always the case. About 30 yds away he puts up a small hut (unyango) for barn or storehouse. About 80 yds from central hut we have a cattle kraal 30 to 40 yds in diameter. Animals are driven to pasture in early morning by younger sons At noon all return, cowsare milked & all then run till sunset when they are penned for the night. The milk at noon is immediately poured into a gourd (ityalo) & allowed to curdle. Native do not like fresh milk. This curdled milk (amasi) is largely used with porridge of corn or maize Women do not interferewith cattle save a mother of bride can choose one as dowry. This animal is called the "ingquter".

Wives cost 11 head of cattle including the ingquter Each wife has a hut & children a smaller one. Work to native is a unfortunate necessity to be got through as rapidly as possible When building a new hut all friends are invited to assist & they do & drink utywala made from maize or corn 
Ploughing
commences about October (spring) Each kraal has about 5 ot 6 acres of land

To scare birds from crops youngsters spend most of their time in field in a tiny wicker work hut (amapempe) & birds are kept off by cries or placing a piece of moulded clay on a rod & switching it at bird like sling

Crops
maize (is staple food) millet, pumpkins, calabashes, sweet potatoes, Kaffir beans & a tuberiferous herb "idumbe" - no annuals like cabbage

Tobacco
is largely grown. Leaves are dried & made into a gigantic cigar 3 ft long & 3 to 4 ins in diameter & the whole covered with native matting & used

as required. Snuff is made by grinding leaf between stone or drying it in sun or under a sheet of tin with aloe roots burnt on top. Leaf is crumpled by hand till only stalk is left & then aloe ash is added.

Reaping
commences about May or June.

Dress
men wear "umtya" &loin cloth of animal skins 
sometimes
sometimesa light blanket is worn over shoulder. Women same. Bead are added. Children also absolutelystark. Baby girls however have the umtya. At 4 or 5 years of age children get a blanket.

The cultivationof hair has been explained before. Kraal owner of about 45 years often wear atuft of feather or a head ring (isicoco). A bride has a head ring of beads (white) which she wearsfor 3 years after marriage. After marriage Wedding dress consistsinitsabsence & rows of beads on head & neck, an armlet, a waistbeltand a square patch of cloth in front and rear open to hip at each side. Children are very free & lovetheir home. Girls nurse babies &youngsters tend herds. Older boys make younger wait on them & perform any drudgery until umnumzanafinds out & then trouble.

Govt.
Each tribe is under a Chief (who is responsible to the local Magistrate) He is assisted by^privy councillor or indunas who report any happening to Chief Tribes are divided into Clans with a clan name (isibongo) like Clan Stewart. The Locations are divided into a number of wards each under an "isibonda" Young men are subject to umnumzanawho is responsible to the "isibonda" who reports to the "induna" who laymatter before Chief. Heir as chief is selected eldest son of principal wife being usually chosen. As principal wife is usually chosen late in life eldest son rarely inherits.

Arts
wood & bone carving is good. Women indulge in pottery & make water urns, beer pots, drinking cups. Material is worked up in soft mass. Then shaped, dried in sun & baked by placing in pole in ground& wood heaped over it & burnt. Grass Weaving for mats, beer strainers, baskets & palm leaf plaiting. Men sometimes do this 

Blacksmith - smithy passesoblong hole 2' to 3' long & 1' deep At one end a long mound of good clay is erected with small hole through centre on basin side coals are placed in hole a horn to large end of which two bags are fastened. These bags are raised or lowered alternately mouth being opened in lifting & closed in lowering. Assistant does this. Anvil consists of ironstone & a smaller piece is hammer. Tongs are barks sharpened at eachend & bent double like tweezers. Soon burnt out. Household utensils summed up = 2 or 3 cooking pots (clay, wooden spoons, eating mats (izitebe) on which meat is served, clay beer pots, palm leaf beer strainers, & several knives. Plates, forks, dishes, cups had originally no wood & were unkown. Now Kaffirised woods have been made. Wheelbarrow oncecarried on head Native women carry 40 to 60 lbs weight eg firewood gracefully balanced on cranium. Water is carried in this way. Assegai only made even now by native smiths often used as a knife. Lamps & candles unkown. Fire gave all light needed also smoke. Fire made by pulling pointed stick in hole of another. The first being turned rapidly between palms of hands contrivance called "uzwati" 

Native mill. A long hollow stone with smooth round crushing stone which is wored rapidly back & forwards.

Grain stamper. Trunk of small tree with stamper 3 ft long with large knob on each end like dumbell. Grain is poured in mixed with water & "pestled" until husk is removed & this washed dried & boiled. Pear shaped calabashes are hollowed from small holes in neck Gourds are scooped out & now used as plates. Althoughusualmethod is toputporridge in one large pot & each one dips his spoon in it in turn. A separate pot is given to women.

Beer is brewed by soaking maize or millet in water till it sprouts. The sprouted maize is then dried in sun ground in mill as described & boiled.This is allowed to stand till fermentation takes place when it is again boiled & put in earthenware pots until ready for use. The process

lasts about a week or 10 days - was intoxicating - served in grass baskets each holding about 2 quarts. Dish is placed in hut, master drinks himself & hands on 
pot
measure till pot is emptied. It is gross breach of etiquette for master to hand anything to his visitors without first partaking Native axeslet intohandles of wood thru a hole Musical instruments ugwali 3' stick with bullock sinews thro rooks quill. Place lips on quill & inhale & exhale

Umtyingo
3' stick hollowed one end cut at angle. Fingers placed over this & other end placed in mouth Isigupu skin stretched over hollowed gourd.

Betrothed
- intro clan marriages not allowed & if made merits wrath of ancestral spirits. Chief often claim 50 or 60 head of cattle for his daughter. On engagment girl with her friends go to kraal & shows her diligence & skill in housekeeping. A goat is killed for her & her friends a feast & dance takes place then bride elect returns home taking with her a bullock to show that she is acceptable to her future father-in-law & his family (If not acceptable she gets 2 head as compensation) Young man continues to visit lady periodically. The lobola (price) is paid by degrees & when complete (or sufficiently complete to satisfy brides father) nuptial knot is tied. On day a beast is killed & beer provided - no invitations news spreads & all are 
invited
made welcome. During proceedings bride receives a charge from her people as to how she is to conduct herself in hernewsphere. After public acceptance of each other the feast proceeds - young people dancing & singing. At close of reception bride groom & his friends go home & later in day is followed by bride & her friends.

Birth & Childhood
- looked foward to by natives not dreaded as by Europeans. Older women of kraal assist & do the job. But if unable a professional accoucheur is called in. A boy (inkosana yikaya)= young master of kraal) is heralded; a girl (umvoosi yomzi)= raiser up of kraal is proclaimed. An infant is smoked (ukufutiva). Several medicinal herbs are placed in a vessel with some live coalsto produce a dense

smoke & child swayed to
wa
& froin fumes. This is carried out every morning at sunrise till child is 6 mos old. Then roots are hung around infants neck with pieces of goat or sheeps skin. These protect child from machinations of evil spirits. Once father was supposed to be absent from
 fix 
home at birth. If chief for 3 mos, if headman 1 mos if commonr14 day) On return to home a great feast & relatives bring presents &father sees child. If caught peekingfines imposed & collected by old women Custom now almost obsolete

Witch doctors
 natural death (except senile decay) impossible. Must be due to witchcraft. & livesare full of superstions.He usually knows everyones business & enemies & for reason of illness or evil assigns your enemy who is as a rule boycotted& find it advisableto remove fromlocality

Native Herbalist
 see under

Entry.34:
-7-18 Wed 34

Censoring again, assisted by Bate & Blackett About 11pm ship turns on its tail & reason is a steamer on horizon which comes closer & turns out to be a British warship on patrol duty & no raider as imagined. Still too wet for parade. I desire to read of War but no parade sports.

26

25 
- 7 -18 Thurs 35

This morning we hope to get in at 6.0 At 7 we are lying off but not daring to enter. View of Table is not possible yet it is cut off by the twelve apostles. This morning we find that ships storehas been broken into & 4 cases whisky - cases of salmon &£10 taken. NCO warned tolook for offender. This is serious in view of threats of an avowed mutiny About 9 we enter & see the Table mountain enveloped entirely in a white shroud. Rain occassionally cuts it out & indeedfor a long time we could not see it at first. After clouds became a table cloth. It is a great majestic basalt rock with a little town at its very foot which it dwarfs & overshadows by it abruptness & grandeur. On its right is the Lions Rump & Head. "The Lion which guards the Land of many mysteries" & as if despised the puny town turns its tail on it & looks out to sea across its body. 
The view
It is only possible to see that it is a Lion Head if seen when Head & Rump are in line with each other. On left of mountain is Devil's Peak. We are examined by various examination steamers a process of about 1½ hours & then sail in about 10 am assisted by the tug Ludwig Weiner. Alongside is a Japanese warship which hauls to sea before our eyes & Λwe give the salute & Japanese



anthem. All officers on boat saluting. Our appearence & steadiness compared very favourablywith theirs. Leave is granted at 2pm We form up & march out the Docks. These Docks are an area set apart for shipping & enclosed between two artificial breakwaters. It is much too small for needs of port & tugs are necessaryall the time as there is so little room to turn The graving dock fairly large & slip as well as all the shipping of port is in this locality. The "Cutty Sark" is here having recently had a new mizzen put in. I go for evening with Major Briscoe a returned MO from East & West Africa & full of information re interior. I spent last night with him in my cabin. We passed out of Dock & examined the pier. - a concrete structure opening out onto acinema& teagarden & closing again to terminate in a round tower. All along sides are bays holding seats for 4 or 5 & in front statue of Jan Van Riebeeck who found the Dutch colony in 1652. 
After
 In 1686 Hugenos arrived owing to Revocation of Edict of Nantes. In 1795 colony rebelled against Dutch & conquered by England on behalf of Prince of Orange & ruled by Eng till 1802 when it was restored by Amiens. In 1806 retaken by British under Sir David Baird & ceded to UK in 1815. Then we proceeded up Adderley Streetexamining the Railway station with its winebuffet & first engine ever on its rails also timetables. Trains are similar to those of NSW tho engines are different & smaller. Next visit PO & saw a stone which was unearthed here P.O was 
original
site of old water place for ships & the steps at one time water edge now rest in museum. Next looked into StandardBank of SA. Most magnificent I have seen. No colours all white with½ roof windows. Then entered Dutch memorial Church very plain & well lighted by electricity all seatsare boxes 5fthigh. Next visited Cathedral an unfinished edifice- only one coloured window - contains several historical flags & tablets to fallen soldiers in various wars. Next visited Parliament House. Tho closed found an attendant & saw

Assembly Hall - much same as ours - Labour has 2 seats only - Unionists (Dutch) Nationalist (govt) then visited Senate - luxurious. Between two is entrance Hall . A marble Hall with black marble pillars & within the whole is oranged by coloured windows It contains constitution & Edward II seal & signature - also proclamation of Dom with George V seal & signature. The dining room is fittedwith small tables & pictures of past speakers & Governors. Next enter Museum which is reached by traversing a park - very pretty but only trees no variety but plenty of Gum & wattles - At entrance to 
Library
Museuma black 7 ft high was superintending cutting off stone of Bushmen drawing. These are splendidly coloured & executed drawing or paintings on rocks.The work is of high order but Bushman is very low. Hence some doubt if Bushman. On
 entrance
 vestibule to Museum. There is a collection of stories. These are letter stories for depositing letter for boat due to call or memorial stories & hashistory of Cape. As follows A padrao erected by Diogo Cão in 1485 at Cape Cross - another at Angra Pequena by Bartholomew Diaz in 1487 Both in German S.W. Africa. Da Gama 1497 - 1499. There is complete life size coloured castes of Bushmen. The original inhabitants of S.A. almond eye. (1) men can suckle young (2) women have enlarged posterior 
with
on which they can live for long periods men have it in slighter degree. (3) minor labi often extrude as much as 2¼inches - always some extrusion specimanis very big Ribbon fish with ribbon of red on it back is peculiar The art Gallery is disappointing & contains no good paintings. Hard to discover entrance from statuary. All pictures of importance are in Michael's Collection in old town Hall - with a Grecian or Roman Garden. Next visited R.A Colly & medical school. meet Drennin see physiology & embryology museums. Rain comes on mountain is lost in mist: Visit university consisting of round dome & two large roomsused for exam & "capping". See Hugenot Memorial Church again with some man who explain that Capetown is Port capital Bloemfontein the judicial & Pretoriathe administrative capital of the Union. Then go to Royal Hotel to dine

Here more so than in Durban it is impossible to get a drink. Then go to Tivoli a vaudeville theatre. Meet two friends withMacqueenPotter (dentist) of 78 Strand St & WH Richards of Richards & Barlow Glass Merchants 131Long St Capetown. Adjourned in trioto Callow Bldg - roomofRichards at half time for refreshment & returned to theatre. Afterwards went to Club whre we were enrolled as Honorary members then to ship. incident withAdam & perser last drink went to bed at 3 am.
Entry.35:
(36)

Piquet duty all day At Wale St Police Station - missed seeing Masonic Temple (see description 16/8/17) But took 36 mile motor drive around 12 apostles - Green Pt, CampsBay, to Houts Bay - a restful hotel and had tea there - crossed Constantia neck thro fertile vineyard into an English locality with avenues of oak trees now denuded of leaves meeting overhead - sometimes for avenues - go to Cecil Rhodes (1) Grote Kunste a Dutch building with everything Dutch in it. Dutch clocks show day, week, no of days to go in month, moon, etc. In Rhodes room is Napoleon clock & outlookis upon terraced Dutch garden & valley of hydrangeas. On table inlaid with silver & bronze made by Hugenots bought for £25now insured for£3000 see flag Cape to Cairo & others - elephant roer -utensils inbilliard room are encased in big chest. Room where he laid in state - dismal to look thro a dead man's undisturbed home. Upstair alcove overlooks vestibule. House is now official residence of Prime Minister. Bed are impossible to ship & big enough for four person. No showers exist in the massive bathroom. Originally building was destroyed by fire & Rhodes erected this on Dutch model & every bit of furniture in it is bought in S.A & Dutch if posssible. Return to piquet dinewith Richards in privatesuniform &agree to meet him at 11 when piquet has returned. He is not there when I return with Scanlon & go on board. I find two stranger Speller & Campbell asleep in my berth(X)

Early rise bath & return to bed to read & then giveup as eyes are bad. wonder if I am only tired or in for influenza. Church read more all morning & chatted with Saintou. Slept all the afternoon. My Birthday - decided to do nothing in way of work today - read Palgrave & spend day with poets In evening stand cigarsfor table& others& find sufficient whisky brought from Liverpool to drink my health. Day isquietly spent.

amid memories that will never fade till time shall cease to be & closer companionship can no one have than his home ones & his loved onewhom he never more may see. Spent night with my new found friends talking of Africa & Ross dilated on lions. Lecture by Kidd on sentries saw whaler & 4 whales in afternoon.

(41) Washing day for N8 no parade - play quoits retire to newly constructed cabin table - works well it consists of 3 board nailed together with cleatsthe exact width of bunk & is jammed intoposition & cannot be moved. I have also invented a wardrobe owing to congested state of cabin we are now 3 instead of 2 to a cabin. Today we practise our new gun which we have taken on board at Capetown. It is a 4.7 Japanese Range 13,000 & is a quickfirer said to do 14 per minute Shootingnot of the best. Practice is about 6 or 7 rounds Afternoon is sports so no parade. Parade as usual but I am occupiedre DCM & succeed in 
apsitting
 upsetting constitutionof the court. At dinner time announcedthat ports may be left open if lights cut off at switch

& guarded & spent most of afternoon looking for switches. These are hopeless owing to alterations made at Cockatoo. They are 
4
5 sets of switches to extinguish lights on our deck. In afternoon write up diary to send home. At dinner tonight McCauley tells of his experiences in German West Africa - lack of water eggsfruit salt - ham& biscuits - Land is fertilein interior but fromsea to 50 or 60 miles there is a belt of desert. Nights are now becoming warmer. sea is like glass & we never have a breeze now. We must be in a calm belt
