Entry.47:
(47)

Continued the court in the morning - till midday In the afternoon parade as usual. Sea is still calm Weather is cool I would have thought it impossible to be so cool under the equator.

7-8-18 (Wed) 48

Land looms up in sight about 7am. Several isolated objects atvarying intervals stand out & speculation makes them the masts of different vessels at anchor. However they turn out to be isolated trees. However vessels do soon appear as weget closer & in number as they are broadside on & seem to float on the horizon they would make an excellent targets. The silhouette is perfect & seems to enlarge the vessels. As we approach we see a long line of buoys with a narrow opening for which we make. Just outside we see a wreck which is most unlike a wreck. It is an Elder Dempster boat which was put ashore by the mate whohad been logged by captain & revenged himself by spoiling a good boat 
wh
because skipper was not on bridge when he should have been

She now restshere 
aft
 & has been lyingthere for 6 years & she is without a sign of rust orloss of a single rope How she keeps this freshly painted appearance I do not know. Perhaps it is the climate perhaps she is repainted. She is surrounded by water & lies inside a reef. Storms do not seem to have affected her. If they have storms here.There is no attempt to salvage here. Before entering two boats flying white ensign pass out - look like minesweepers. On entering formalities are few. On right point is covered with dense tropical undergrowrth - seems unhealthy Coco.are here but do not seem numerous As we pass up we pass various ships including Moreawhich is to be our escort. She is now an auxiliary cruiser. Current is very strong a 4 knotone &tears past boat We have arrived in the rainy season of year. Weather is very cool due probably to the overcast sky.Though when it is bright sunshine it is not very hot. The town consists of a collection of houses clustered at foot of a large hill - barracksare on an isolated knoll & a few houses on top of hill

The white popoulation is about 200 & the remainder black. A fine physical race but VD whosesole delight is eating & women therecost about£5 & morality is very low. Their language is Mendibut nearly all speak a sort of English especially the swear words. Fruit & fish vendors come alongside in canoeshollowed out of tree trunks & paddledby a native in stern Fruit is hauled up in a basket in which the money has first been lowered. They do not trust soldiers. Prices are exorbitantbananas 1d a piece & fish 1/- each SMO forbids them vending as place is full of malaria. For this reason no one is allowed on shore. We pass the day gazing at shore. Some say we only stay here 
4
8 hour but no attempt to coalyet made though it commences at 6pm.
Entry.48:
49

Coal has come alongside in lighters - all coal is bagged &is welsh. It is bagged on collier & placed into punts of about 250 tons. These punts are placed alongside ships bunkers ports & staging of 1 2 or 3steps as required are put up & coal is passed by gangs of 50, in pairs. One pass to next pair to next right up to bunker holes & bays thrown down to punt. The work is done by the negroes who receive 2/3 per day of 02 hrs& 6/-per night of 11 hrs(6pm till 5am). They load 13 to 18 bags per minute (each bag is cut) when working but they talk more than they work. On one occasion during 1 hour they loaded 13bags. Their system of tallying is noisy. One individual count for each bag with all the noise he can make with a weird cry for each tenth bag.^ 1.1 more
Entry.49:
tally-ho tally one.Another enters it on tally. Theconstant calling & yelling grows very monotonous expecially during the night. 

Day is not very hot though many are sleeping on deck. This morning there is little current. This is due to fact that there isa river at head of the bay & when is running in this banks up & on release current is rapid. I do not know if this is real reason. Native boys in their logs come out this morning & dive for silver they ignore copper - pretend they cannot see them. They fall out of boat & sink below coin which

descends very slowly & invariably catch it. They then climb into boat a very difficult operation. Other men in boat steadying craft with a paddle on off side. Two men Todd & White are adrift - got ashore last night in lighters. The natives handle all trip & the wonder is they manage to keep them afloat. They are fullof dents wherethey have crashed into any handy obstacles. Their knowledge is nil but somehow they 
carry
muddleon like our Govt. At dinner the negroes are disgusting. Their food is sent from shore about 12 noon in big dishes. They sit round it & pick it out with their hands whichare dirty from handling coal - they never wash. If too much in his mouth he spits it back into dish again. What an opportunity for spreading disease. Their yabber is excessive. After dinner they sleep where they are in the coalanywhere.
Entry.50:
50

Spent allthe morning judging the physical training squads & in intervals watching the waling operations & the alleged seamanship of the tug captains. Then play off my quoits match & in muddle of it man falls overboard. Chips goes after him & rescues him but is himself borne away by current. Boat is lowered after a while & picks him up & then tries to sail right back in teeth of wind instead of tacking When it gets back its wind is cut off by ship & it falls to rear again. Then it rows & gets alongside after a long time & catches a rope but current is too strong & away goes boat. A launch with wireless men come along but refuse to assist in spite of all entreaties beach goes on. The blacks here are the cheekiest I have seen & seem to think they are on an equality with the white men. At last boat is brought aboard & chippy is cheered In the afternoon boxing is continued between Brennan & Hollingshed & at night usual routine dinner, smoke on deck, retireto cabin, undress & read M. L in cabininpyjamas. Brittania and in Brazilian fleet 2 TB destroyers storeship & several destroyer

Sailing day. Got off earlier than expected about 6pm We proceed out in a long line Morealeading. It is a pretty sight. The scenery is picturesque long line of low shores fringed with lakes& behind the cloud piercing summits of rugged hills. The wreck looks like a vessel putting into port. Outside we form toodeep and afterward the calculationsare incomprehensiblenow one formation then another sometime in square & sometimes under One fact I notice is that we are always in the centre. It is comforting to know we are in a safe position I spoke a lot this afternoon with Saintou & make him my orderly. Price supervising him. This 
afternoon
evening before dinner I speak with Belgian officer Lt Barbier in French so far I have avoided doing so but he has asked me to do so. Iask him to have aperitif but 
he
I must watchthe arrivals& so have not time. After dinner usual routine

Entry.57:
57
Shower - no cold water - shave - & back to bed to cool & frame a charge - Smith comes down & chargeis settled - Inventory taken of mensutensilshammocks & blankets to find amount to be levied to cover breakages & deficiencies. In midst of which I am wantedfor court as witness in Vernon'scase. act as troop deck officer & judge tables. dinner - meat mostly fat - afternoon played quoits & lost place in tournament - slept because eyes are tired Usual routine after - at night went on deck. Moon blazed a silent track across sea missing the dark objects the ships which like hidden danger lurked on either side but which the path to glory missed. & I passed many hour far in to the night with the beauty which eye cannot see & the music only heard in silence.

From earlier
 26/7/18

Iron gate on the base on which is written Loge De Goede Hoofe Gov 1772 Winding path leads to building See plan 

Chamber of S--e
Figure of white draped woman with one hand on mouth & fingeron lips signifying silence. Walls are dead black - Roof domed - no furniture save a chair. This is first in which he is taken after prelimexam. Here C-S- & W given & a secret lecture on value of S. If decline to go on can retire if goes on he is left to meditate on lecture He leaves room by twoinclinedl_sHere he is blindfolded & 2 BB assist him over l _s while lecture details meaning. Bandage comes off & he is lead out He is not at this state prepared for chamber This comes after second chamber.



He crosses to opposite door which is shaped like Triplewindow & is 4" thick. Massively built & bolted resembled dungeon grille. raised panelling. A peep hole in arch part. Height so low as to cause a stoop to get in Statue of man naked with cloth thrown across body resting on elbow facing down head thrown back 3 cuts blood running down breast. ABC contain emblems of M -

Far side has similarly constructed door work. bottle shaped hole in archedpart into which a bottle of similar shape is placed - which contain pure crystal water behind which a light was placed - now electric but system was earlier than this & water used as a lens. Effect is ghastly on S Y = stone bench - no back Left here in solitude for 1½ hours If for 1 goes back to main hall If for 3 goes ahead.

A tunnel 6' to 10' long & dark - no door this end but iron grill Bible set in 1749 has never left - his room since 1772. is oblong 7' x 4' & 2 ft deep - Seatbehind grill is 4' high dais in recess about 4' high. dais has three seats but inclined. Whole approached 1 step & curtain on flank. No windows.

Main Room. 3 windows in wall & electrically lighted in rear. representing 5 points, S&C, Head. Roof is rounded but ridge 4' wide in centre - painted. Thunder & lightning at will Pyramids &white with clusters of candles sealed along side Humility - strength - Floor 5 ft high approached by sick. at this end together, seats at side broken in centre. Dais there for 3 Far dais for 4 all in dutch. Door hammered out in course of year & a new bit inlaid

Next room contains about 30 of WMS including one of Francois Renier Duminy . Some are photos some only sketches also contain the old charts from Holland & other documents 

Entrance Hall. different charts oron walls has a table & desk

History
. Founded 1772 WM generally seafaring men descendants of same are still in here. Course takes 3 years
Entry.58:
Sea still calm - water blue as if under seaborn skies Convoy is becoming monotonous as in always see same shirt in same place at same time. Better the empty sea for we know that this is not the same as yesterday. No company for drill as all are on musketry or duty. Usual afternoon program.

At dinner Elliott Cook very nice. Concert after dinner & then wet night. McCauley .
Entry.59: Service this morning - went for a change & glad. Padre Gorrie sermon was a treat: he his farewell remarks in afternoon compiled account of lady with Browser & CSM afterwards Gorrie & Millikin. Wrote up diary & war report.
Entry.60: Sea calm & quite blue. smoke on horizon. After breakfast Morea bolts to sarboard at right angles Object is boat looking like Empire but flags a green flag probably Brazilian. She has not answered promptly enough to our signal Morea still seem unsatisfied but does not pursue & leaves her alone - No parade as men on musketry. pay this afternoon & distribution of pay books. Morea at 4pm goes off on another ramble to starboard & then drops astern hang in rear for a while & then comes through convoy passing quite close to us. Coe Hughe invite to a party to morrow. After dinner lectured by Ross on Cyclist corps & then bar, then bed.
Entry.61:
Informed by Penlyat 6am that I am deck O. Officer & refuse to get up if he can warn in the day before. I am dead tired this morning but am too busy to have a little nap. Judge the best







table this morning & then inspect the paysheets. then kit inspection at 2pm interval. 6d collection for breakages. 3d for chaps who saved the Sgt up in the shark infested water of Sierra Leone. 2/- for magazine. i have so far taken 3 copies. Morea has not taken any shoals to day. After dinner to night took table to see news & then wrote diary & then visited decks. Found 2 ports just opening impossible to detect offender but it was N9. reported the matter.
Entry.62: Rose & dressed by 8. Sainton says I am lazy he is funny. He roused on me this morning for not allowing him to wash my clothes & said I was to dirty. He is very attached to me & will do anything for me. I forgot to add that he is my orderly the little frank chap met in Market Street. This morning there we have changed position with Oanfa. This is at first sight worse for us but when escort joins us a TBD takes our place & we drop back into the centre. we hope to pick up escort tonight or to morrow. After 5pm all ranks must wear lifebelts by day & night. Tomorrow all port holes will be closed for rest of voyage so that in case of boat being hit & listing the water will not fill thro portholes & hasten matters. Busy now inside cabin this does not apply to me. Hair cut this morning - arranged my case to see what things I have - run in potato race this afternoon but was beaten in the heat. This is first exercise I have taken on board & being a distance of 200 yd with stops to pick up potatoes was very solid & I was not the only one knocked up. This afternoon Morea went for a walk & hung in eye of sun on left rear for some time &then came back. It is now very light for about 1½ hours after dinner. Talked with Campbell re trip to Scotland & Northumberland & then talked with Hammond re Indian service & then to diary & then bed
Entry.63:
I am officer of submarine guard & go on duty at 9 am & remain on 24 hours soon after 10 am. a periscope was sighted on starboard side Morea wheeled on her caul & started at full speed for it. My feeling at this moment was peculiar. I was full of interest & was concerned that submarine should not escape before Morea could ram her. I was only keenly excited in race. If it had really been a submarine the danger to ourselves would have been real & in a few seconds our boat would have been gone but while we thought of the possibility my feelings were only those of interest in affair. However the periscope turned out to be an upturned cable & Morea let it pass. so did next boat Yokohama but the last boat front up E (submarine signal) & we alarm 6 whistle & turned her stern on to it so as bring her gun into action. However it was unnecessary. While on duty read hand book Memoirs d'une longue chaise & wrote home as mail closes today at 12 noon. Escort is expected to day but so far have not seen it. As all my 3 sgts on guard are only Cpls & as Cpls are only available. As 5 out of 6 are under 19 years of age & sad to say awake all night The Bar closes tonight definitively; There is a wild happy reunion. After the final flutter go up on deck & yarn with Ross. While yarning see a boat float by which however occasions an alarm from forward sentries. 1) lay down about 2 & at 3.30 there is wild rushing overhead on bridge & clanging of telephone bell. wheel is spun round & there is a babel of voices. thinking something has happened which guard has not warned me of I rush outside & find night quite calm & peaceful. Moon is shining brightly but a cold wind is blowing & occasionally a shower. Good night for submarines but sentries are all alert. However submarines guard would be of little use & it is all are

in ranks by order of adjutant.
Entry.64:
About 6.30 am 6 black spots are seen extending from one side of horizon to the other. One of these spots is flashing with electric signal lamp in the moonlight. Searchlight here extend for about 4 before & 4 hrs after sunset. Soon these black lumps are seen to be 3 funnels 130 & they circle round & take up their position. They are handled with perfect seamanship & one of them runs up under our counter passes a line on board & ties a packet of orders to line which is drawn on board. It is a knife edged trim little craft with a roll that seems incredible in this calm sea. One signalman excites admiration as he stands on a plank without guards or railing ropes or anything to steady him but he moves & he seems quite at ease & for the moment one thinks he must be stuck on the remain there but he moves & this disproves this theory. Am relieved at 9 am & go till 1 pm & then lunch & read all the afternoon. Now find that we will not land till Monday at earliest & then at Tilbury, so perhaps we will hear the finish in France before we get there. Water is running out & washing of clothes is prohibited. Taps in officers lavatories are plugged. prolonged journey casts a gloom over ships & we are 3 more days in life belts. To night we had a splendid concert. Maclean & Gordon are excellent singers. They were all officers & are excellent voices as good as any concert platform will produce. After concert were on deck & though a bright moonlight night could only distinguish 1 destroyer. All other vessels very visible in the clear moonlight:



bout 8.15 on horizon on port-bow a convoy of 12 vessels apparently no escort - though a few small vessels looking like trawlers were among their number. On horizon an airship c 60 appear & attach itself to us a large aluminium 3 conjoined cylinder affair looking like a seagull the floats underneath resembling feet at a distance Car contains 6 men & she carries a depth charge one of which is missing. Thenpassing over convoy. Another one is seen at breakfast but it attaches itself to the other convoy. Air ships float majestically over as now a silent witness to Englands might. (The first airship view over usat 6 am but Iwas in bed) About 11 it moved with her 2,000,000 bullion accompanied by Sheridan the slowest boat in the convoy & 2 destroyers leave for Devonport whither we originally intended to go. Airship C10 still remains the white ensign fluttering defiantly from its tail & the union jack underneath the fore: About 10 this morning two destroyers wheeled & let something fall wheeled again & then signalled supposed to be a submarine. One ship in other convoy fired 3 shots. Toward noon a seaplane came over circled round the other & crossed & recrossed apparently handing over orders & then bigger one the one whichaccompanied us all day returned to her station disappearing at an enormous rate: after saying goodbyeto us At noon we were supposed to be off Falmouth? - land on the horizon has been visible all day & at 3 is very plain. At 2 pm we are off Start-Point. After dinner air craft have left us & we are left with our own TBD less 2 with more away on starboard quarter is Cascade light. Sunset is glorious to effect is marred by two grey clouds. Moon rises blood red & looks at first like a ship on fire asrest of orb is visible Air is cool & flu prevalent. Rumour now has it we are bound for Havre.
Entry.65:
Beachy Head is abreast this morning awhite chalky cliff looking as if it had just come out of a landslide. This is England at hand & does not impress me as it should: just past see Eastbourne a sea side resort. Two immense buildings are hotels & are some size thothey cover more ground than their height justifies. Next we pass Pevensy Bay where William I landed & then Hastings. Next Dungeness with its light. Land appears pasture land but is really farm land. Windmills the emblem of Eng are seen here & there & clumps of bush. All afternoon out of sight of land. A submarine was sunk 17 miles in rear of our convoy this morning by an airship. Entrance to channel we pass a fast & large convoy going outward. The number of sights no end to them fills one with amazement at the British navy power. ThoGermany sends out hersubmarines yet it seems powerless to affect British shipping. Destroyers of all shapes & speeds surround us. Early in morning 3 airships (silver fire) sweep over sea in our direction & trawlers underneath sweep for mines. Aeroplanes sweepers everywhere. French coast is invisible owing to fog. Fishing boats carry on vocation regardless of submarine. 5 Barges are towed off away from France. Our hospital ships come across with wounded. Pass Dover with its false Harbour at 1.0 pm. Warships & channel boats visible old time Castle where Henry VIII invaded France across overhanging hill. On right a harbour lies 5 masted the largest sailing ship in world which went ashore before war owing to big rope breaking 2 masts still remain. land here is farmland divided by hedges or trees. White cliffs of Dover are now dirty owing to soil washing down them. Pass south & then

South Foreland. Goodwin Sands with 3 masts still showing & enter Downs. lifebelts are discarded, happy relieved all vessels leave us though every boat fly white ensign & even towing boats seemed to be armed with a gun. Last RBD has apparently no funnel looked a speedy craft. Pick up Pilot in the Downs & then proceed. Enter Estuary at 2.45 pm & pass up river. land is flat on water & slopes back to hill. All is cultivated no towns or houses. River is barricaded around ground. houses are quaint & ancient style. First people I saw in Eng were farmers & men of a farm with square shape.

Passed a boat which had been upended cut in pieces & each piece lying tied to bank. Finally anchored at Gravesend or Tilbury Dock - its the same 
thing
place. Left here 3 am.
Entry.66:
Found ourselves at Albert Dock & woke up about 5. Reveille 5 am no sleep camedown with influenza. Disembark 9 am & train came 11.30 by Great Eastern & S.W.R to Fovant in the south of Salisbury. The undulating country with its vivid green & dense clumps of trees together with harvested hay defies all description & it is such scenery as I have never witnessed before a sort of refined beauty not the vast rugged grandeur which it has always been my lot to see I saw in reality the pictures of McWhirter & whose painting I have often studied. But amid all the beauty the suspicion of a congested population struggling for existence & living satisfied with little. Stopped at Woking & reached Foran about 4 pm disembarked & my troops went one way & I went another. Army officer Major Blake is VC & Capt Lindly is Assist Adjutant & alsoPMO of SWS . The officers are a very nice lot & everyone does all they can to make

us comfortable. WAAC attend to us. Concert party here tonight & party afterwards in mess singing a little dancing & much merriment. As influenza is still bad & blow on neck from craneon ship still sore I retire about 11.30 but get no sleep till 2
Entry.67: Still down with flu. Wander round camp in morning & in afternoon was awakened to check equipment. at night too ill to sleep. Molesworth refusing to take breakfast parade for me. Took Dover powder to treat cold.
Entry.68:
Owing to fact that breakfast parade brought me out of bed at 6.15 influenza increased rather than decreased. Worked checking equipment all the morning. Retired early & nursed influenza as leave commences to morrow

29-8-18 Thurs
Spent morning preparing, collecting cash railway passes & meal-tickets Here if one wishes meals he must give a coupon before he can obtain it or even purchase it. There are in the books coupon is enable person to buy 1 weeks ration of lard, tea, sugar. However I am not drinking tea & sugar I take golden syrup with porridge. Bacon & eggsdo not come under the heading of meat or other meats (other meats includes fry.). By permission of Capt Lindly who knew me at Casula, obtained leave to get away by the midday train altho my leave did not commence till midnight. Molesworth is coming with me & we have to curtail our dinner. I pack some unnecessary things (boots, pyjamas) which I would not take if on my own in Molesworths bag & to keep

matter along & allow Molesworth to have a bite I hurry on to carry port but pass it in the middle of the path. go to tent & my room & then return to find M. waving astick in air& pointing to the bag which is plainlyvisible at 100 yds. We then hurry as train is almost due to start. M. then remebered he has left his overcoat behind & returns for it & carrying on the good work with the bag which is above my weight. As I struggle on a bounding form in rear draws near & says if we are too late we will be back here together & offers to buy my ticket for me to save time. This is Major Kerby. he does & we enter nearest compartment which unknown to me contains two lady friends of his Mrs Hill & Miss Phillips. M not in sight but draws near as train is moving out. Train waits for him & he bundles in. Pleasantries are exchanged between these 2 unknown women & ourselves Major omits to introduce us who he pictures as rapscallions, Bill sykes etc. We only go about 1 mile in this car & then arrive at Denton where we change & I get change to repay major. M book his ticket. We travel with Major & his friends to Salisbury where all change again. Major friends here go off inviting me to come & visit them at Fovant major is coming on with us. Train arrives but is crowded. It has a dining car on board & major conceive idea of buying a meal for the sake of the seat. Girl attendant says we must go when we have finished our meal & we tell her we will stayfor afternoon tea & any other meals that may be necessary to permit us to retain our seats. The three of us then commence a race to see who will be the slowest. Meal costs 2/6 & tea 1/-

but as journey took 3 hours it was worth the money for the sake of the seat. On arrival at Waterloo decided to take a taxi see one empty & beckon it. He merely points to the inside & refuses to move. If we want taxi we must walk up to it & this we do as taxi is essential to us. M gets off in Chancery Lane & Major soon afterwards I continue alone to Threadneedle & leave car in Basinghall St & set out to find Chamber. Thanks to a handy tongue & people conveniently placed I find it without difficulty. The square is approached thro an iron gate which leads into an alley & then opens into a Court in the centre of which a large tree flourishes. By an insignificant entrance with winding staircase I find office & am announced as another khaki officer. Mr Alcock is very nice & sends a cable home for me (costs me 6/-) & gives me a letter from Sydney the only one to arrive dated
Entry.69:
Enquire where is Charles Agency & Mr Alcock accompanies me to find out & when found it turns out to be closed. This is awkward as we must start tomorrow without any walls. I then walk back to Chancery lane to pick up M. & I now lose myself in this great alley which is only 1 mile square itself. There is little difficulty finding ones way in the alley itself. The Streets are narrow & traffic is not heavy. The tale of asking a policeman toescort you to an island & then rushing the remainder is all a myth. Its not as difficult as Macquarie st & the narrow streets make negotiation easier. Together we tramp through this interesting city. see Trafalgar Square & are admitted members of the Royal Automobile Club then to marble arch a huge & ugly memorial arch composed of white marble which looks coal dirty

Trams are double decker & they move at a slow speed. Taxis are conspicuous by their absence & after waiting some time for one we get a newsboy to find one. Tipping here is universal & everyone is looking for a tip where we hesitated as to which way we would go an urchin of about 3 & his smaller sister demanded where we wanted to go & could they help us (for the sake of a tip).

As we have no desire for dinner we omit it & go to theatre. Drury Lane happens to loom up & we go there perhaps attracted by two Australian names playing there Dorothy Brunton & Ivy Schilling. The theatre is bigger than any I have seen in fact too big for the voices of the actors which seemed lost in the entourage who played in "Shanghai Theatre is beautifully decorated & has 4 tiers in house. We come out at interval & make for Custom where we are staying for the night City is weird with its absence of light & indeed it is difficult to find ones way
Entry.70:
We rise 6 & go to Tube & thence to Charing Cross as we hope to find a taxi there & this is the easiest way to get to any place whose whereabouts we do not know. In fact Lee's amusement is to set out for some place & when we have hopelessly lost ourselves call a taxi to find ourselves. But this morning not a taxi is to be seen but nevertheless we find our way to Club & await pleasure of a barber who never seems to be there. I in despair decided to shave myself & find a dressing room with hot & cold water baths etc & shave & bath myself while M is merely having a shave. We must find out that train does not start till 10 instead of 9 so we decided to have some breakfast. Before this we decided to do without it. Breakfast consists of porridge (no sugar only syrup) & fried sole (the nicest Ihave ever


tasted & 2 poached eggs. No meal tickets are required for this as coffee is without sugar. In midst of breakfast M starts off to meet Lees who had expressed a desire to travel with us & had to meet us at Kings Cross Station. M. is not heard of after this He apparently went to Charing Cross. I see Lees on platform but he is detained at Horseferry & cannot accompany us. Have not seen M. Train starts Itis 22 carriages long. In my compartment are 3 flying cadets One has lived in Victoria for many years. Imight say I only just caught train as it took nearly a ½ hour to catch a taxi. The Club porter running out in middle of road every time he saw a motor & waving a red flag. We pass thrusuburbs of London & am surprised at the freshness of the rosy cheeked girls in factories. Women are everywhere in this land doing a mans work whether in the field or factory If necessary for the work they wear a loose bloomer arrangement. Country soon comes into view & consists of multitudes of pocket handkerchief sized farms each surrounded by a pretty green hedge. The fields alternate between the straw colour of ripened crops or the verdant green that only England knows. We have nothing so green in Aust: & it is only here that one learns the meaning of the word green. "Talk not of green till Eng you have seen". Often a field is straw & tinted red by myriads of poppies In Kent I believe the fields are straw with stripes of red. On On we fly thru the pleasant fields of Lincolnshire which weary by their features. This fen country is very flat. This is succeeded by the flatness of the Yorkshire moor which the harvest is still as dense. The fields on which harvesting has commenced are still full of the piles of ungathered sheathes. Everywhere it is the same & in fact in the north the harvest has not been touched Pass thro Grantham & on thro Durham with its old castle perched on a knoll overlooking the river and as defiant as of yoreguarding & protecting a huge monastery as heavy as itself



Further on on same side is a more modern castle situated pleasantly in a clearing in the woods for the country now has some dells & dense woods. Then run into Newcastle the great city of the North & great indeed it is Here I must change into forward part of train In Eng if you do not change trains or carriages every two or three stations you know that you are in the wrong train. Never have I seen such a place to change. Here I make friends with a Melbourne man & a Dr from Edinburgh. Country now becomes seashore as Line tends to come on to the coast. In the distance one can see Holy tree & its monastery famed of old & between it & the line feature sand banks on one of which lies a small wreck. From now on to Berwick & for some distance past it we are in the old debatable land & relics of old towers & pillars are numerous. often only a foundation stone left. The hedges have disappeared & all divisions are by small stone walls the cost of labour on the execution of which seems to me to be out of proportion to sheer value. They are loosely placed one on the other & no mortar. It seems a good strong wind or a snowstorm would cause them to collapse. We cross the river & see the old image of Berwick below us. The old castle wall of the old Castle is now part of the station & the train passes through its once impenetrable barrier. North of Berwick which by the way once read in proclamation as distinct from from Scot & UK as "& the town of Berwick". We now skirt the coast line running on the top of cliff while often a fishing village nestles at foot Here & there we catch glimpses of trawlers while on rear is a naval squadron & to the north a large convoy. Ruins abound everywhere here We pass the Battle of Dunbar & then Prestonpans & after a while run into the outskirts of Edinburgh On the left stand Holyrood the chapel end in ruins the other part more or less preserved.

On arrival at Edinburgh at 8.00 it is still light & my friend takes me down Princes st the wide & noble thoroughfare of this city. & which constitutes the main artery of the new city the older part being on the other side of what was once a loch & now is a fertile valley used for railway lines. Across this valley placed in an imposing position the Art Gallery while in rear is old Edinburgh Castle with its square castle of the Stuarts its batteries & frowning walls. At bottom of valley lies the old water supply of the castle. In Princes St stands the huge memorial erected to Walter Scott & if ever a man deserved a national monyment it is he for without him & his work the country would lose nearly all interest. It is only because Rob Roy lived here or Rhoderic Dhu fought there that many places have any interest at all. Unable to find the officers decide to dine at the Caledonian hotel & sit a table with two medical students from South Africa or rather they are doctors at the infirmary. One has had a birthday & has been celebrating & invites me to join in the party. One of them Dr Volthuter arranges to meet me at Frasers Lothian Bar near Lyceum theatre tomorrow at 7.30 pm but I will be far from here to morrow. I have great difficulty in getting a room & go to Troussiers Parisien Cafe Duke St for supper. Lees train arrives at 4 am to morrow & I have agreed to meet him but I dont think I shall be out of bed at that time.
Entry.71:
.
As did not meet 4 train I go to all trains leaving for Callander to intercept Lees I visit Waverley Station & he is not on 8.10 am the next is 8.55 am the one I am travelling on. I walk round castle visit old quarter of city & buy a paper which speaks of Billy Hughes as the

Premier from "down under". Holyrood is shut until 9 am so I cannot enter. Have a good view of Calton Gaol a huge edifice erected for a gaol but constructed exactly the same as an old Castle & it is hard to believe that it is not one. I catch the 8.55 am at Caledonian Station & proceed north having as a companion Lt A.G. MacLaren 3 Bn Argyll & Sutherland Highlander from Allans Water who points out the places of interest Sir Wallace Monument and the site of Battle of in rear on left the site of Bannockburn & the hill where the camp followers massed & led Edward to believe that a fresh army was coming into action Pass thro Stirling with its ancient castle & blood strewn battlefield now verdant fields. MacLaren descends at Bridge of Allan & I journey alone to Dunblane where the inevitable change takes place & I spend the time in the old Cathedral which was erected in 1240 & contains traces of 3 sisters Euphemia, Margaret supposed wife of James IV& Sybyl all of whom were poisoned & interred at foot of the altar in 1501. Then see castle at Doune one of the oldest in Scotland. Today there is a flag over it as one of the family is being married & my friend a Highland Captain is going to the wedding as it is his cousin. MacLaren has been full of enthusiasm for the Highland scenery & has mapped out an itinerary for me different from what I had intended. He recommends me to have a meal at a place kept by one Cramwho has been in Aust. I arrive at Callander & find Cram. He is in the bakehouse (they are bakers & pastrycooks) & I go there & explain that MacLaren has sent me & have a yarn & am adopted as their guest & given carte blanche of whole house. I spend a half hour looking over library. Then dinner commences & a pleasant one

it is. Food here is in plenty as flour etc is used for bakery purposes & bacon is not rationed. After dinner one of the brothers then details himself as my guide. We then go out through Kilmahog past an ancient mill run by a sluice from river. On past a church of 11th century of which all which remains now is the bell which is in centre of gate. A stone wall made from stones of old church & now surrounds a fairly old burying place. Then we commence to climb one of the high hills on the top of which is Samson's putt a large stone of a different composition to anything seen in the neighbourhood. It is supposed to have come down in a glacier & the glacier dissoved here. Samson threw this stone from one hill to the next & as it was before breakfast he had not strength enough it fell on a low lying hill in the centre. From this point (wherethe bridge was very strong) we commenced ascent of Fordoun or Drum Mohr on two sides it is protected by a series of ditches with two bastions on which is a well still with water in it. It is said when Water lockon Kennacker was put in spring was cut but nevertheless water was in it when I saw it. It is said that somebody intends to dig up this well for weapons but if iron they would be rusted & if flint of no particular interest. The fort was impregnable in old days & was of British origin as Romans never built on a hill. The remains of an old Roman camp below - all that remains is a wall or rampart with a raised portion in centre said to be general headquarters.

The view from this hill is magnificent. Ben Ledi is near & whence the stag started in the "Lady of the Lake" while the place where Scott stayed is seen nestling among the trees. In the distance is seen the Wallace Monument. I gather much bluebells & heather which I will send home also some bell heather. Also my friend gathers some blueberries for me. We descend & cross river on a quaint old bridge. All bridges here are built on a semicircle & if river is broad the arch rises above the road we have a steep rise & fall in road. Stepsseem unknown. We then wander thro wood & shaded walks back home passing on way. Near house is a round mound palpably artificial & much speculation exists as to its origin. It is probably a funeral mound. After dinner at which I could not eat enough to satisfy my host. Peter Cram & myself set off on another tour this time to Bracklynn Fall. These are reached by passing down main St in which his home is situated. here Itry the bag pipes & can not raise one note. The road to falls is ascending & wild the country however is not of such ruggedness as on the other side. Away in the distance I see a white tower which is supposed to be the centre of Scotland. After visiting the fall we walk along the thickly wooded burn for some distance - past a once famous castle of which only a pile of stones about 4 ft high remains & home by shaded walk where trees meet overhead passing on the way an old crazy woman & her home. That night we have supper & yarn until after 11 pm & am dead beat & long for bed. It is a magnificent room they give me
Entry.72:
Am to leave Callander by 9 am train for the most rugged & aweinspiring part of Scotland. Train is not to time when all two bells are rung to announce it arrival if from the north one bell only. Girl at station (they are all girls on railway) tells me to get out at third stop Glenogle siding. Sunny is mountain above & sparkling lakes or lochs below. We pass Loch Lubnaig, then Loch Earn & Loch Lay. Lochs are silvery waters nestling at foot of enormous barren craigs. The squared end of Loch Earn is peculiarly pretty. Two men in carriage insist that the other line train has stopped is not really upthere but an occasional one & my real stop is further on. Hence I stay on train which flies past next stop & lands me at Luib 7 miles away still I am glad. The day is before me & I find myself in valley between two rugged hills with Ben More at end of valley. Mists sweep across & I have every possible view of Ben More. First back in sunshine & purple with its heather then slightly obscured by mists with the silvery white clouds peculiar to Scotland in rear & finally wreathed in clouds. Valley is very pretty with its ripened fields & quaint houses while aspath goes on it winds near to the River which rustles by hidden by a thick screen of bushes. Anon it breaks into a shallow turbulent mountain stream full of eddies & breaking over stones & making minor cascades. Several times I put on my overcoat as the mountain mists overtake me only to take it off again when the sun shines out. Met a seaman near villageof Killin & speak to him re Australia. People here all speak Gaelic. The entrance to the village is the prettiest I have ever seen. On left runs a low stone

wall below which the river forms a series of cascades dividing itself with an island densely clad with trees & mosses only to meet again & fall into cascades under an old bridge which was overhung by tall trees on either side while on the right is a series of old fashioned verandahless thatched cottages end to end & old fashioned in the extreme while between the river & the cottages runs the winding road. Below the bridge river divides round an island with very high & dense trees. This dreary isle is the burial place of the N'etal & its dismalness justifies its choice. Passing into the village I see the usual old mill year 100 years old & worked by sluices. In the village as I have an address I go to it but it is full, same on second floor & so on. At last I find a place & close as I do not expect to find boarding house in this little hamlet. However I soon discover there are many boarding houses & even a rather fine hotel. Having established myself I set off to view the ruins of Finlarig Castle a castle erected in 1607. On the judgment mound is a holly tree about 3 ft in diameter & on lawn a sundial with 14 faces made by the old monks. Just outside the ruin in a hollow square pit connected with dungeon by underground passage. It was here that he gentlemen of noble birth obtained the privilege of being beheaded while on other side is the hanging tree with a branch at a rightangle about 3 ft in diameter tho this has disappeared but the tree is a veteran compared with the others. The ruins consist of a turret a few rooms including entrance door with the royal arms quartered above it. Walls are of loose stone about 9 to 13 ft thick. The place is now kept in order & surrounded by a stone wall made from ruins which preserves the ruinsas the neighbouring village has been built from it.

The custodian is an old veteran of the tourist guide type interesting & garrulous. i then go along a beautiful wooded path where trees rise 200 ft high & meet overhead to the Loch Lay & rest on the pier. The sunset is sublime & tranquil which the shadows of the peaks & densely wooded shore in the still waters of the loch give vivid reflections. I return to tea which is served in the room which constitutes sleeping room & dining room. Mealis bully beef & treacle owing to shortage of rations & unexpectedness of my arrival. I have fire made up & washed my socks & dried my clothing & went to sleep. I must start tomorrow by 7.0 am train back to Callander.
Entry.73:
Trip back is same as coming below the loch above the crag & the purple growing so close that one can almost touch it with the hand. Arrive in Callander about 8am & go to Crown who have breakfast waiting for me. I then walk out to see the Pass & Falls of Leny which is reached through old loch gate (Rent 800£ per annum once) at Kilmahog past the Roman camp. The path as winds is overhung with trees to such an extent that though it rains I am not wet. Falls are pretty (see picture) & I return in time to lunch & good bye tomy new found friends & get a box seat on the coach for the Throssachs. When train arrives Lees & Molesworth turn up & get on a coach in rear. The trip is said to include the prettiest scenery in Scotland but in my opinion it is just as grand further north. The road runs past Drummohr (see before) past duct round with Fitz James & Coilantogle Ford to Loch Venachar glistening in the morning sun. The road leads us over the Brig o' Turk where last



boar in Scotland was killed. All these places have Gaelic names which the old fashioned coachman with side whiskers loves to give us & amuses us very much especially as everyone tries to pronounce them & someone will ask his neighbour what did the driver say was the name of this place.

We halt half an hour at the Throssachs hotel a stately mansion with alcove in the dining hall hung with curtains. Having luncheon at Callander I do not repeat but ramble down in the Loch Ackray thro wooded path & gaze at the hills which rise sloping steeply back from the rosywaters of the loch. (By the way there is only one Lake in Scotland Lake of Monteith where Mary of Scots was imprisoned. On resumingwe enter the Trossach Pass "where twines the pass etc". The road is overhung with trees & winds in out among towering hills visible only at intervals finally finishing with one immense crag called Rod look out on edge of Loch Katrine. Here we take ferry the Sir Walter Scott & pass alongside of Ellen's Isle a small densely wood isle not worthy of a hiding place for an outlaw & opposite it a silver strand. Most of the Scottish scenery owes most of its interest to Scott & whole lines are quoted about spots we pass which otherwise would be unnoticed. We pass down Loch Katrine & land at Stronachlacher Hotel which is closed & await arrival of coach which is a four in hand. We pass by Loch Arklet & are amused at piece of tin hung on telephone wires to prevent the night-flying grouse from running into the wire so coachman said. We get out at Inversnaid Hotel & for 1/6 have a cup of tea & bread & jam. Visit the Inversnaid Hall near by but have not time to visit

Rob Roy cave near by. We then take boat down Loch Lomond & recall the strains of Bonnie Banks. Ben Lomond looms on our view an unscalable peak but on other side is quite easy to walk. We pass Rob Roy's prison. We are in Rob Roys country & everything has some connection with him. This part of Loch is narrow & hemmed in by craggy & bare hills while lower down it opens out hills recede & numerous densely wooded isles come into view in one of which Inchmurrin is ruins of an old castle tho little remains of it. The lochs are all very much similar & one tires of them so much so that we decided to cancel our trip to Loch Fyne tomorrow.

We arrive at Balloch & take train to Glasgow. Railway Hotel is full & a friend whom I have met in train intercedes for us without success. We try several hotels & get in at one we do not like Lees so back to & finally we get in there & are very comfortable.
Entry.74:
Still with Lees & Molesworth & subordinate my scheme to those & am not as well satisfied as if I had remained on my own. We visit & a Mrs Anderson goes to no end of trouble to arrange a days outing for us. We then set out to visit Art Gallery & walk through it & see nothing tho it contains many gems. Next we return to city lunch & go to National Projectile works, a munitions factory - nothing interesting - girls do all the work which is machine lathing & turning. Shells are delivered forged & then are turned to crrect size - then bottled in process below & then returned & turned again & again then varnished & dried in furnace inspected & despatched. Labour saving devices are rare &

visit was not worth time spent there. We then returned & caught train to Trossachs to connect with river steamer to see the shipyard.

Informed steamer leaves 5.20 but in Lord of the Isles only arrives 5.40. We pass by many yards often as many as 10 ships berthed alongside each other only a few feet separating them. The boats are of all class from battleships to trawlers. One indeed is queer The Argus she has an immense superstructure hollow above her deck & squared & level we put her down as a balloon carrier. We pass the Yarrow yards & Harland & Wolf on the right. The yard or rather two yards for there is only a church & two rows of houses separating them & these have recently been purchased is a larger plant than at Belfast & is used up to its fullest capacity. On both sides we pass shipyard after shipyard with boats in all stages of construction. We pass old Dumbarton Castle & the residence of Denys of Dumbarton the great shipbuilder. His yard is further up Clyde. We reach Dunfermline & book seats at Alhambra Theatre - stalls at 1/10deach. The performance Be careful Baby is given in two sittings one at 6.20 & then at 8.20 pm hence the prices. We then return to hotel. breakfast at hotel costs 3/6 & consists of Porridge, fish & eggs bacon dinner is 5/6. Voyage passed Lanark steel work, Glasgow shell - coal mine & other enormous mounds - station Abington Beattock Lockerbie.
Entry.75:
Lees & Molesworth set out for London by 9 am train & I for the English Lake district by 10 am for Penrith to which I duly arrived after changing several times according to custom. i pass thru Carlisle but have not much time. On arrival at Penrith find a car ready for Ullswater & driver gives me a box seat. Am informed that I must catch train here tonight in fact had better





stay at Pooley Bridge but find my informant is daughter of local innkeeper there. I catch boat down the Lake. This is prettiest lake I have seen. It possesses all the rugged & aweinspiring beauty of a cultivated locality. At first densely wooded hills slope down to waters edge & then land recedes into pleasant hills & farms as we go on the cultivated aspectdisappears & bluff as wild & rugged as any in surround loomed up on both side from after leaving Howton view is particularly aweinspiring. I land & am lucky enough to find a coach going to Ambleside whence I can catch a train tonight for Bristol. The drive is magnificent & well worth taking the risk of missing a train. Away in distance is High Street the ridge on which the old Romans built their road & later Higher Bell the highest point in the street. It is wonderful the level ridge they chose. We pass by Brothers' Water where two brothers were supposed to have drowned. A small but pleasant hill edged lake. Then coach enters the Kirkstone (pronounced Cuxton) Pass a narrow ribbon of road shut in by closed piercing crags of loose stones. After a while we have to walk & land at Kirkstone Hotel one of the highest licensed houses in England. It is 1481 ft above sea level. We have scones & milk then sign the book & hear the adage that only a fool takes a coach in Kirkstone for everyone walks. After we pass a sign Dismount accidents have occurred but if we obeyed all signs we would never be in the coach. Pass now descends rapidly & driver puts a shoeon one of the wheels which henceforth toboggans down the hill. At Hotel is a good echo which coachman tries for us. The descent is dangerous in extreme but horse knows the way & driver is confident. This road is not often

used on account of its danger but another via Troutbeck which is 5¼ miles longer. However we are late & driver takes the risk much to terror of the only lady on the coach. Slate quarries now unworked are numerous & Helvellyn is in the distance. Arrive I go to White Lion Hotel intending to visit RydalWater & Grasmere before dinner. However I see the new church & dine at 9.30 & intend to retire early but yarn with an officer & the landlady till late into the night & then sign the book & turn in for the night. Hotel. Bed 4/- Dinner 4/6 Breakfast 3/-
Entry.76:
The last day of leave intend to spend day travelling stopping for a while at Bath. Motor 6/- to Windermere for train at 7.25. The number of time & changes today is innumerable & the connections awful in fact it is just 12 when I arrive in camp & I have had no time to visit Bath. At Preston I have 1½ hours to wait & visit town. A Gallery & Museum with Egyptian painting a wonderful scheme done in water colours. I think I see the site of Battle of Preston & some battle relics visit the C of E church & also St Wilfrids the RC church a magnificent interior with marble columns & costly altar. Rejoining train again I get as far as Crewe where I decide to dine as I have another hours wait. Then I wait again at Shrewsbury then another train in Pulford where I have tea on 2 cups of Bovril & sandwiches. I detrain here as by waiting 1 hour I need not wait 2 hours somewhere else (Newport) & will get to Bristol quicker. I go through the Severn tunnel 3 miles in length 7 minutes journey actual part under river is 1½ miles &¾ miles tunnelled approachis said to have cost£2,000,000. Pumps are kept constantly at work. At Bristol I have to rush to No 1 platform to catch train for Salisbury there is none to Denton or Fovant & arrive at Salisbury 10.35 pm get a taxi & then ride for camp like the devil

Though the night was dark we must have averaged 40 miles the horn was going all the time & the fog made driving uncertain. Journey cost£1 & as I am strange to Fovant it takes me some time to find my bearings but finally reach room to find a different inmate. The wild drive was a fitting close in a day of delays & rushes.
Entry.77: Report at Staff Parade to Lt Todd & am detailed to report to him later at his office at 8-15 am where he explains organisation of camps & advises us to change our equipment for week & that we are to go on a funeral this afternoon of Cpl McIlrich one of my men. Ceremony like all military ceremonies is impressive. Route is picturesque thro the village of Fovant a pretty place thro which runs a river opening at times into cress beds & all others flooding north of the road which as usual winds thro leafy lanes. Arrived at ceremony padre is not there but finally we lay our comrade to sleep in the peaceful old churchyard far from the stress of battle which he had come so far to share. Strange are the ways of Fate that one should come 12,000 miles to find a resting place in a small English hamlet.
Entry.78:
Route march today & it is worth the march. We are on Salisbury Plains but Fovant is not on plain itself but the edge of it. A large hill back in camp & on the side of it in the green is all the devices ofvarious regiments who have been quartered here. These stand out for miles & one is of the rising sun of Australia in each of the rays of which 50 man can stand. The march is thro delightful country. Surely no place was sweetly pretty as

an English village & its lanes. One place in particular an overhead bridge approached by a leafy shaded sunken avenue was memorable. We arrive back at 12.15 & sleep for afternoon & in the night while everyone else is out I bring diary up to date& hope to write letters tomorrow.
Entry.79: Breakfast is at 8 this morning & then left 11.35 for O.T.S. Carried no rifle like others. All other officers on boat are joined in this school. We are 12 in this room Elliott, Varsons, Molesworth, Little, Uren, Crighton, Penly, Chow, Lees, Davis, Naigh & attended a lecture straight away.
Entry.81: day at this school which I am informed with musketry school at end lasts 8 weeks. The day consisted of lectures & one little part of drill in afternoon. Walk to village in afternoon with Paroon & return warmed. Wrestled with Uren today & smashed a bottle in my pocket & had to wash my clothes.
Entry.82: Slow work today - nothing of interest to relate.
Entry.84:
Day topography. We had to find our way. The old house at Tedworth



is a magnificent old home now used as an officers club. The walks around here are glorious. The old trees meet & there is a green grass underneath to which the sun rarely reaches. The spots are ideal & the walks magnificent. At one time we reached a plantation & there were avenues cut into it - leafy walks which never lose their beauty. Here it rains several times a day & then sun comes out between showers. with such weather conditions trees & grass could not but help to grow. Even the trees having green moss right up their branches &those that have not are shrouded with small leaves & twigs. The effect is same as you see in the old pictures. It is indeed worth coming 13,000 miles to see the softened beauty in this country which is never harsh, never aweinspiring but is inspired spiritual loveliness.
Entry.85: Too wet to go out stayed in & answered questions in class, slept & took hot plunge in afternoon.
Entry.86:
Compulsory church parade 9.30 & all marched to C of E church a new building with square columns & round arches giving a flat suggestion to the archiltecture. Aeroplanes pass here all day & night sometimes singly sometimes pair but generally in flights of 7, 8 or 9. They perform all sorts of wonderful manoeuvres - winding around on side - falling headlong from skies without engines & then regaining control looping the loop among others. By night they fly with electric lights on their planes. It is truly wonderful what they can do. ut they are so common & frequent that it is rarely we take any notice of them. After dinner to night we went over to Tedworth House & which is now an officer club. The

walk there & back & this shady clump of beeches I think I have described before. The house is full of large rooms & has a lovely conservatory a long narrow building with sweet smelling shrubs on one side & on the other chairs the passage ending in a large cupola with tree ferns & other exotic plants.
Entry.89: Nothing save usual routine. We have been constructing fences of barbed wire the last 3 days & are glad of the week end in order to grow the flesh on our hands. Outside the window where I am sitting there is a pool of rain water in which the starlings are washing themselves - they are not so dirty here & even a little sparrow with much trepidation has joined them perhaps because dust is a negligible quantity. It is always raining here never bright sunshine for more than an hour without a heavy shower of rain. And now a chaffinch the first I have ever seen has joined them. The building adjoining us here is a hospital filled mainly with wounded Huns. Indeed Huns are plentiful about here wandering about under Allied Guard but too well content to make any attempt to escape.
Entry.90: Church this morning - on way home see11 planes overhead in the same quarterof the sky. They resemble a flock of birds.
Entry.92: Nothing save usual school of Instruction work -
Entry.93: Rode on bike to Stonehenge & Amesbury a distance of
Entry.94:
miles returning by Chorlderton a smelly little village with a ditch running round it which is crossed by several brick bridges. Each quaint old house stands back from path & is full of flowers even at the late period






the roads are closed in & compressed by the hedges which rise above you on either side while the approach to Chorlderton is through an immense avenue of high trees. The country is flat with one big hill where view is superb. The old church at Amesbury musty with damp & agedcolumns 15 ft square & dead above & below was interesting whilst the view from the stone bridge looking up the avenue was picturesque. On return I was dead beat had a warm bath & lay in my overcoat for 1¼ hours & got flu.
Entry.95: Went into hospital this morning temp 102.6 & remained here on starvation diet called subsistence till
Entry.97: Without being allowed I get out of bed & walk round the room as is usual & was ordered to get up & go to Clive House - a convalescent home where one has nothing to do but eat & go for walks & get strong.
Entry.98: Went for long walk the word with Cotton a friend who has invited me to Bournemouth if leave is granted.
Entry.99:
Went on long walk delightful woods where above the trees are all the tints of autumn leaves & below there is a carpet of the same below while the straight branchless trunks look unreal. The blackberries are in profusion & very ripe. I left the beaten track &rambled for hours thro these woods where the sky is never seen & the growth is luxuriant. The rides in the woods are always overhung & the trees on either side meet in the centre & tho underfoot ground is wet one will forgive much inconvenience for



the pleasure of seeing this sylvan beauty.
Entry.100: Light showers make our walk impossible this morning soI just stay indoors & see the sloping lawns with dark strip where countless hedges cross them showing between the meadow strip or else the white ribbon of a road in the distance a row of trees at regular intervals planted as if for ornamental purpose whilst on the low hills on the plantation in all their rich verdure clothes them to the edge of the foothill.
Entry.101:
till 28-0-18

Still the same old convalescent routine - eat & walk. Be in for meals & out not later than 9 pm. Class of officer here are ill bred illiterate slips of youths of the RAA who have mastered the principles of flying about as much as their principles of English & having crashed down & destroyed valuable property arehere recuperating all they can damage some more. One hassmashed his plane in to wreck & another was so rattled that he does not know anything of the earlier stages of the accident. Truly the type of officer is nothing like the old RFC officer & it is no credit nowadays to be associated with such a class.
Entry.102:
Mothers Birthday - impossible to send anything from here & even if so it would be too early for her next birthday. Lt Col Goddard visited hospital to day. This morning M.O. had sent me to DADMS to see if I could be transferred to a convalescent home but it appears from Aust HQ view that I am British & from the British Hospital people that I am Aust & so beyond their jurisdiction so neither does anything & I stay here with a cough that the heavy fogs round here do not help. I explained to Col that I was trying to get away from Tedworth & the result he asked me if I would ask for 48 hours leave to which I said yes & asked if he would not make it a little longer. He could not grant more than 48 hours but promised to extend it if I wired. There are two trains to townI am informed 4.10 pm & 7.35 pm. As I must get my things

toge& let the bed free to hospital for the night & incidentally get more leave as I should have an extra night in London. However at 6 I find that this train does not run & ring up station to verify same & am told that staff is gone to dinner but if I ring at 7.20 or 7.30 I might get some one. I am about 2 miles from station as I am compelled I decide to stay here for night.
Entry.103:
Ask orderly to call me at 6 but as his clock is 1½ hours slow it is lucky I can wake myself. I bathe shave & get a snack of food & arrive at station about 20 minutes too early. However leave does start & I get as far as Andover where I change. I chum up with an officer from Wiltshire who like every true Britisher never knows anything about his own country. I decide to see the relief of Home guards at Whitehall. This officer tells me to go down into the underground railway system with him. Normally I never go underground as I invariably get lost. I should have changed at Charing Cross but this intelligent scion of the noble English race did not know this & I was landed very far away from where I wanted to go. When I arrived at Whitehall the guards had been changed. Two mounted men motionless on motionless horses in a little box are on duty. Their dress is the armour plated style of ancient knights through which scarlets & blues flash & dazzle ones eyes. Inside dismounted men with clanking swords & dazzle of brass etc stride with clumsy steps in & out of the arches. I pass thro to St James Park, a park composed of winter grass covered with the fallen autumn leaves which no one has had time to gather up for the park in front is a Royal palace it certainly needs some supervision. Across park are low trip wire supposed to be a fence. The Palace Buckingham is a big solid looking structure imposing but not beautiful. The guards were changing the Welsh were relieving the Scots Guard.

The performance was nothing to speak of I have seen our own men as steady when occasion demanded. In front of the palace outside the Gates is the enormous unfinished statue erected as a memorial to Queen Victoria. I then set out for Horseferry Rd the Australian Headquarters a quaint red building with a large courtyard of grass & then bigger building beyond altogether rather a large place in spite of its small facade. Having drawn all pay available I go down to Commonwealth Bank to visit it & adjust my accounts which have been muddled up. The current a/c has been transferred fro Aust & put into a savings bank account in this Strand Branch while the savings Bank a/c has been transferred with a note that it was not to be operated on. However I saw the manager Mr Finnly & all was straightened out. Time is now near one o'clock. I thought of Jack Kennedy & decided to go upstairs & look him up. Sure enough I find him & is quite surprised as I put my head round & greet him with "Hello Jack". He shows me through this enormous 7 storey building constructed from Aust. marble & prisoners. From the roof I have a good birds eye view of London with St Pauls dome one end & Westminster the other & below us in a little island in the street is St Clemens Church of which one has heard before in the old song Oranges & Lemons the Bells of St Clemens. The same old bells are there now. We go down stairs & see the library a magnificent chamber with pillars of marble brought from Australia as is also everything in this room save a big carpet which weighs about 1½ tons & cost over£1,000 & was made in Donnegal. We go out for dinner Jack as my guide & I as the leading spirit. I decide to go to Pinolli 17/00 Wardour St. (Regent 1664 phone) off Coventry St Lunch 1/6 (noon till 4 pm). Hors d'oevres, soup, fish, meat or Poultry, Vegetables , Sweets & Cheese. Dinner is 2/- & consists of 8 courses with salads, cheese, & sweets as courses. After Luncheon we walked throughout Soho & saw all the places once dreaded by law abiding citizens. Now all is

quite as any party of the city. We strolled in & out looking at the small shops & innumerable cafes & restaurants. Then to Legrand Gerrard St for a cup of coffee. Here a separate brew is made for each person. After this we made a tour of theatres including John Bulls office where 300 were roasted alive in a raid. Then to Covent Garden theatre a palatial building now used as a store but in front of which is a trumpery gas jet light vastly incongruous with the structure. then to the Market. Here it was Paddy's market without its life. The prices amuse me Grapes 8/- & 6/- per lb. Peaches 4/- & 5/- each Pears 2/- & 3/- a piece, small melons 1 ft long & parched looking 15/- each. I asked the vendor if anyone ever bought at these prices & he seemed surprised especially when I told him I wanted a case for that price. This is not the slum part but was originally & until the formation of Shaftesbury Avenue the foreign part of London. All the cafes are French & Italian or other foreign elements as are all the shops. Notice in window states that "Here one speaks -- " Here & there especially after nightfall one meets a chap that looks his part but the whole Soho is peaceful now & even frequented by many of the richer class for here only is it possible to obtain a good meal in London. The large Hotels go in for glitter & shout & music & the food part of the meal is forgotten.

We go to Regent Palace Hotel for afternoon tea. The Lounge is the largest space seen with a big circular dome rising in the centre with a glass
roof. Everywhere little tables & easy chairs at which tea & cake is served for 8d. The lounge has marble pillars, palms & much gold decoration & is known as the Rotunda Court. Many women are present, but English beauty or the apparent beauty for the beauty if existent is often covered under a cloud of paint & powder, does not appeal to me. The vestibule to Court is very large while the entrance is thro a circular glass door revolved by machinery & at first takes some judgment as to exactly when

to attempt the passage. At side are two ordinary glass doors. Time is now about 5 & it is dark. We start off looking for hotel & wander from one to another till we have visited about 15. Finally find Dean Hotel with an attached breakfast in red red blind & little candles on tables with red shade & having settled the place of residence we went out to dine at the Rendez-vous. However this being full we went to "Au petit Riche" Le rendezvous des Gourmets 44 Old Compton St London W. phone Gerrard 5988. Here we dined intending to go to the theatre at 8. At 8 we had only finished about 3 courses out of 8 at 10 to 8 & so missed theatre. As we were too late we decideto Colosseum the largest theatre here. It is vaudeville & you can go in at any part so as it was a good meal we lingered over it till 9. At one part I got annoyed at the slowness & lapsed into French & thereafter head girl came round & chatted & showed me books she was reading. She is naive as other French girls. When we arrived at Colosseum Jack asked for seats & though girl had just given seats of a medium price to 2 people as soon as she saw me she had none below the highest price & as I thought I was being got at I refused to go there & we wandered down to Strand Corner House for coffee & refreshments. The place is owned by Lyon who is the Sergeants Ltd of London & has places everywhere. The Corner House has a roundopening within, aroundwhich the floors of 4 or 5 stories run, the band being on the lower floor & sound travelling up thro opening while down below is the Hall of Mirrors which is not very much. Then at 10 we left no supper is seved after 9.30 here. Arrived at Hotel I yarned with Jack in the vestibule & then feeling done up retired to Room 111. There I tossed about on bed until after 3 am. I had smoked heavily during the day after a long abstinence due to impossibility of purchasing cigarettes of Turkish or Russian

origin. Whether it was the tobacco or the fact that I had overtaxed my strength which I had got & am not as strong as I thought & several times during the day Jack was very anxious. I am satisfied that this old heart is not yet fit for active service but I will carry on with it just the same.
Entry.104: Rose 9.45 & went for shave. First shop no one in - next was for ladies only & the third was all sorts shaving, manicure & chiropodist. The museum is near by I walk down to it passing on the way Mudies & many other names I know. The building is now almost all closed up only a few of the rooms of the Graeco Roman period are open. All the rest is closed so it is impossible to describe it. Disappointed I took bus to the Bank. The bus system is excellent. They run every few minutes, travel very fast, pull up where required & are as cheap as our trams. While from the top one can see London under ideal circumstances & as seats hold two it is easy to ask names of buildings on the way. All along I see names familiar to me on Customs invoices. I go to Alcocks but there are no more letters - indeed I could hardly expect them for on
Entry.105:
I got 6 which I have not yet answered. Mr Alcock then takes me round to Mansion House which is closed as Lord Mayors Feast is soon to be held & then on to St Pauls Cathedral. I enter by the door neath the dome and find myself under the enormous dome with its Listening Gallery round the top of it. It is much like any other church with glorious stained windows & memorials to the dead. Half the church is devoted to the clergy & choristers. The statue of Nelson is undergoing repairs. I go down into the crypt to see where "high ambition is



lowly laid" & pause before the tombs of the victors of Trafalgar & Waterloo & the funeral car of Wellington on which are encircled the names of his many victories. One tablet appealed to me. Just an inscription to the dead who perished in the old Cathedral & whose bones lie somewhere under the crypt. Names include & Duke of Lancaster. Near by is St Pauls Churchyard a little park with a monument in the centre on the very spot where the Cross of Old St Pauls originally stood. I then wander along Lombard St to Fenchurch St to Mincing Lane to see Mr Pettit but he is out & I return with Mr Alcock to take him to dinner. He heads for Sweetings a London business with many fish restaurants all over the city. Meal is good but not startling. Fish called plaice is nice though a little too soft in the flesh. After dinner I set out to see the Tower about which I will say nothing as guide book I am forwarding gives all particulars. Here I met a U.S. officer who asked if he might come along with me. Soldiers are admitted free civilians pay. The old beefeaters in their clumsy uniform edged with red cord with short mantles. These now act as a sort of police of the Tower coupled with the duty of guide. The moat is dry & used as a parade ground for the marines. The guides insist on your seeing everything but they are much the same & we did not feel inclined especially as my limbs are so weak to wander up towers for the sake of saying we had seen this or that particular piece of stone or room, an attitude which the guides could not understand. However our tastes were similar & we left to see the abbey but as it was too late we went for tea to the lounge of the Bristol Hotel Burlington Gardens. then we came through city again. The majority of people in London do not know their way about but will never refuse to direct you or admit ignorance consequently you are often sent in an opposite direction even though you are

almost at the place where you want to go. After being at such a place I was directed to go 5 streets away in the opposite direction & when things seemed wrong I asked a bobby & he told me to go back to the original starting point - I opened out in good Australian on the fool who had directed me. The outburst staggered & then amused the bobby who hoped that I would not encounter the individual as he forecast visions of a fight. We dropped in to the Regent for another cup of coffee really to put in time as it was too late to go anywhere & too early for dinner: Here my friend met two girl friends who took me as far as my Club & then to cafe au petit riche where I had an appointment. Without them I should have been lost as I find my way in daytime by look of building & at night all is changed. London is a city of darkness. All lights are out & the street lights are shaded or blue. The main illumination is the small headlights of the motor omnibus. At cafe my friend did not turn up & the dinner was Bohemian. The French waitresses remembered me. An English officer came in & sat down & afterwards joined me. Two ladies at the table near by joined in conversation but there was no forwardness such as one would expect in an English cafe if same thing took place. The atmosphere was different. Rain came & I went back to automobileclub for an overcoat where I met Miss Dolly Lox of 12 Albert Mansions Baker St. As rain is heavy do not go to theatre.
Entry.106:
After Breakfast which I had in bed I set out for Mde Tussauds (see catalogue). This is inferior. The faces are in some cases not true to life (eg Cromwell) though the costumes are. The Chamber of horrors has nothing horrible in it save criminal relics & murderers who after all are men like



the rest of the community in appearance. The collection of Napoleonic relics is good & interesting whilst the guilotined heads of the French Rev. are worth seeing. There is a large tea room in the building. Many of the exhibits are difficult to see owing to the decreased lighting arrangements. From there I went on to the Regents Park with the Botanic Gardens & Zoo Park is very desolate & the fallen leaves give it an unkempt appearance. The numberof perambulators & babies is very great, it seems the babys promenade of London & in fact the only place for that I have seen babies. The Park abounds in squirrels & if you have a nut in your hand they will come across the green & eat out of your hand. Dogs are not admitted to park & the squirrels run no risk. The Zoo for a large place like London & allowing for deterioration due to deaths & inability to replace animals, is decidedly poor. The specimens are not of the largest kind. The arrangements for heating rooms & keeping the animals from the warmer climates in comfortable quarters are excellent. But the smell from animals kept in artificially heated rooms must be overpowering. The bears are there separated by a ditch as at Taronga but the monkeys are still in cages likewise the lions & tigers. Lizards snakes & tortoises are kept in hot houses. Here I asked a keeper where the gorillas & orang utangs were kept & after repeating my question he replied "The way out is up there". Strange I cannot make myself understood in English. From Zoo I crossed to High St (down Park St) & caught bus for town, where I was advised to dine at Royal. However this was full so I tried Carlton Hotel, Trocadero & other places noting the arrangements in each & the menu. I am satisfied if one wishes to dine well he must seek the foreign restaurants & not the big & showy hotels. So I set out for Restaurant d'Italie 26 Old Compton St Soho where Luncheon is 12 till 3 & Dinner 5 to 9.

This is an Italian restaurant with excellent brands of Italian wines. The dinner for 4/- is the cheapest, largest & best cooked meal for the price. In the small room I occupied a french girl & man were at one table. A theatrical manager & his fiancee sat at my table & the far table contained some English ladies & the remaining table was occupied by an English colonel & some old male friends in frock coats. Quite a mixed crowd & so interesting to me. Most English women smoke in public. Young boys of 16 & 18 wear hard little hats & carry sticks quite like little lords. After dinner I set out for Mincing Lane & at the Bank encountered the first traffic jamb necessitating a few minutes wait till a gap occurred in the fast moving traffic. The motor buses travel at full speed & need some dodging. There appears to be little slow traffic & one must keep your eyes open. At present time motor cars are few owing to petrolrestrictions & this minimises the traffic. Thence I went to Pitot but he was out so I retraced my steps to city to Westminster only to find Abbey closed whereat I vented my opinions on the autocracy of a priest who shut up the possessions of the people. But the poor chap said it was not his fault. Then as I did not want to walk to Parliament house to repeat same story & seeing a YMCA enquiry Office nearby I dropped in to make enquiries. I found that Parliament House was closed but that a party would start from here at 10 tomorrow with an experienced guide to see both Abbey & Houses of Parliament so I decide to form party & meanwhile returned to city. Seeing a nice shop with shaving over door & red curtains I went in only to find women. They explained they could shave as well as a man & I submitted. Shop is in Macclesfield St. Then I booked a seat at Daly's Theatre Leicester Sq WC2 (Phone 201 Gerrard) for "Maid of the Mountains" & then to Club for room. Club is full & I am directed to Enquiry Office. Man says which hotel do you

want & threw me a sheet with about 30 hotels most of which I had tried on previous evening. It appears that the military reserve a certain number of beds in all big hotels for military officers especially from overseas & given an order to any hotel. Thus tonight I find myself at Regent Palace Hotel. Then I step round to 1 Hunter St for supper & then to theatre. Dalys has 4 tiers but is not as big as Drury Lane. The priceis excellent &music good.
