Programmes cost 6deach. After theatre I went back to hotel & had some cocoa & cake. Whilst sitting two of my old sgts now cadets in Air Force came up & spoke to me. They were going away to Oxford in the morning & each said they were only too glad to see me as each owed me a£ which was worrying them. We spoke for a long while & then we all went to bed. Bates & Minnetwere staying here.
Entry.107:
Met Bates & Minnet in Lounge at 8.45 & we went into breakfast together after which I left them as I wanted to form YMCA party at 10. On arrival it had not started & then was a wait for some othersto join in. Amongst the waiting party were 5 YMCA girls from America one of whom had torn her dress. I helped her out of her difficulty & we became friends. The Houses of Parliament are the most magnificent chambers I have seen & are well explained in the guide. The statue of Cromwell & a massive equestrian statue of Richard I are the only statues adorning the exterior of Westminster. Cromwell was buried here in all the pomp possible & on Restoration his body was dug up - hanged at Lyburn & head put on a pikestaff outside Hall where it remained for 25 years till staff rotted. Now his statue is one of the two on outside of Hall & from pomp to degradation to pomp again such is the wealth of fame. We saw vast hall once a Banqueting Hall, Star Chambers, Court, where Wallace & Charles I, & Stafford were tried for their life. The


spot where Charles I stood during his 7 days trial is still marked with brass plates. Then we entered the Abbey (see Guide) hoary with age & history & full of the ashes of the famous dead. As we move among their tombs we feel instinctively that we are touching all that is great in English history & the responsibility of our duty stands exemplified by the influence which the past sacrifices & memories of the dead overshadow us. Leaving here I proceed to London. The greater part of London is not London but the city of Westminster. I step in Carlton Street quite different from ours then Royal Cafe, Trocadero all of which places it is impossible to get a seat unless you have booked it in advance - a thing that revolts me for I love to wander without plan & to be committed to no set scheme of action but more like the wind where I listeth. Finally the name Elysee Cafe in 244 Coventry St catches my eye & I go in - see M. Card. It is said to be a replica of the dining saloon on the Lusitania Table 76. Luncheon 4/6 Bass 1/4 & is very nice though the Italians do not make good waiters. In the afternoon I took a bus 15 to the slum quarter of London down Aldgate, East India Dock Rd, Blackwell Tunnel, Poplar, East Barking, North Woolwich. These slums are much the same everywhere small houses but few tenement buildings these seem to exist nearer the city. Salmon Lane is a lively street & is dangerous. Chrisp St is an avenue of shops buttressed by two rows of costermonger barrows in the gutter while the crowd is thick. The way they eye me makes me verify that my pockets are buttoned especially one which has£20 in it. However I got back & had a look at Petticoat Lane about which more later. Dinner I had at Trocadero, one of Lyons places & a place so fashionable that you must order well ahead to get a place. However I found a place & had pleasure of seeing people line up in a queue among the tables waiting for a place whilst otherswandered among the tables seeking a place. It was like having your meal in the streets & everyone envying you

your place. The service was damnable. The waiter brought me my wine with my ice & I told him off in public& as he had not got his tip he was afraid to answer back. The food was poor years behind the foreign restaurants. Still it is as well I went for purposes of comparison. I met here Lt Hay from Hendon with whom Ihad a drink & then I caught Tube for Waterloo & thence to Hospital arriving there 12.15 am & squared the orderly on duty to keep quiet.
Entry.110: Went out taking photos. This is the first day with sunshine for 4 weeks. Thought I must be back in Australia again. The trees here are becoming desolate & depressing. Their black stems looking like limbs twisted in deaths agony though the carpet of autumnal leaves laying in their last sleep in a brown velvety carpet on the ground is a sight one can now but remember.
Entry.111:
& 7

Met an old friend of dads - Mabee - now a cattle breeder in NZ & 2nd Lt in NZA. we went out for a walk & are firm friends.
Entry.112: Went out for walk over to Cholderton& then in afternoon with Mabee to Sudbury where there is an old Celt fort consisting of two deep trenches circular the inner one 30' deep & about 50 ft across. I plucked some holly from thehill, also some hawthorn which I am forwarding home.
Entry.113:
All English officers who have had flu have been granted 4 weeks leave but all colonial officers must remain in hospital until fit for discharged



What a pity one is a colonial sometimes. We have had several days with sunshine here but even though sun is bright the landscape is clouded with mists. Such is the manner of England.
Entry.114:
Tuesday
Armistice was signed 11 am yesterday. I am desirous to see how London takes the news. I apply for 48 hrs leave the longest allowed to colonial troops but decide to commence my leave today. In all I take 5½ days an extension of 48 hrs was allowed & the balance taken. Left by 4.10 pm & arrived at about 7 pm. made friends on train with a naval officer & went with him to Chandos Hotel. Drinks are impossible bar is ever full to brim but few are drunk. We then adjourned to a small little cafe in Greek St kept by a man called Gustave where the food is excellent though the appointments are not on the same level. Here we consumed many bottles of champagne. Then we go into the street & strive to make our way through the crowded square. There is a dance at Regent Palace Hotel but crowd is too dense to approach it & we go to Cafe Royal only to find no admission. However by various ruses & lies we stepped in. Inside the room was a howling seething riot shouting & cheering. All more or less drunk the women generally more. The atmosphere was revolting & I escaped as soon as possible with an English captain of the Gloucester Regiment. In wandering around the streets we found two distressed women who had not been able to get anything to eat & instead of advising them my friend in a quixotic humour went from restaurant to restaurant until we found & he insisted to my annoyance on seeing them to their train. Had they been young & pretty perhaps I should not have minded but one was at least 50. I then wandered in & out & among the crowd which was noisy &

amusing itself in the heavy clumsy manner that characterises an Englishman when he attempts to be gay. The munition & war girls form the bulk of the crowd & nearly everyone is drunk or getting that way. Civilians & girls take the bulk of the throng & enormously outnumber the soldiery though these increase in number after the first few nights. The forms of amusement are generally of a horseplay character. (
On Wednesday
the guns weretaken from mall to Trafalgar Square for purpose of being buried. The students from Bart hospital rescued them after a severe fight with the crowd. The gates at Regenet Palace were rammed with a gun carriage but held though it took two days to repair them.

Circles of dancers of all sorts were everywhere. Rings were frequently made round the police & ring a rosy indulged in. One circle consisted of land girls & kilted scots - the order of clothing had changed.. Motors & taxis were afraid to come near the crowd. Any which did were assailed by soldiers & girls who scrambled on top. Every car appearing in Piccadilly underwent this treatment. On one taxi roof a merry quartet danced until driver accelerated his pace & one couple fell off the top. The girl got a nasty shock but no serious injury & the two revellers continued their gambols on terra firma. The police interfered as little as possible with the jubilation even when the cannons were burnt. The granite base of Nelson's monument has been damaged. Last night (Tues) the crowd burnt the YMCA at base& when fire brigade turned out with the hoses & the whole square was inundated. Fireworks are few - although there are some. Anything will attract a crowd here. A man selling feathers put a paper hat on & a big crowd immediately collected. A group sings a song & crowd stops & collects. General form of celebration is to form a procession. Trumpets or drums or bugles lead the way. Roughness

if you are in the way is certain. The crowd is not open free & joyous as our own but each part keeps to itself more. Francis day in Australia resembles this celebration but there was no confetti battles as there. The only real gaiety I saw was a group of Italians in Soho who danced for sheer joy & not for sake of cuddling or being cuddled. In Piccadilly I saw Randall & allied myself with a Belgian officer whose knowledge of English was very limited. So far I had not a room in which to sleep. The Belgeoffered to share his bed likewise two older Belges but I thought this would be too uncomfortable & at least they might be comfortable in their own beds. The Belge then wandered about the streets with me & at about 2 am we came upon an adventure. An air force officer had been thrown out of a two storey building by some women & was wallowing in his blood strange to say not killed by his fall. The police raided the place & here I met another Belgian a waiter at the Coventry & his girls who were waiting to go home by the Tube at 4 am. Time was now 2.30 am. We all five then went for a walk to get warm & I thought AAC could put me up with a blanket at any rate cover so we all walked in that direction & by luck I slept in another mans bed.
Entry.115:
14.11.18
15.11.18

The doings of these three days are very much confused & I cannot now divide each day into its travels so I will lump them. The doings each night are as abovethough I stayed at different hotels.

Richmond & Kew. I took a bus out the way & passed through different styles of houses. In some places the houses had been

built before the streets & were so high that you had a broad wall with a series of steps approachingit. Atanother there was a picket fence on this terrace. Harrodsis a great big place now so large as A Hordernthough it is a much larger. The Kew gardens though they may be beautiful in summer are certainly dreary in winter when the leafless limbs are unrelieved by a spot of green. If only these Englanders would plant some evergreens like spruce or pine on the exterior edges they would make their parks more inviting. But it is another case of as it was in the beginning etc.

Kensington Museum both natural history, science are well worth visiting. The collection of clothing & tapestry in the Royal Albert museum is excellent though a little wearying to the ordinary visitor unless he has some point to settle. The natural history is part of British Museum which contains nothing of this kind.

Tea rooms. Visited Cave Tea Room in Strand off Charing Cross under Dunn Buildings an underground crowded smoke filled basement where the waitresses are exceedingly pretty. Baltic Tea Room 39 St Marys are also underground but nicer than above. Bluebird in York Place Piccadilly a neat little rendezvous place with cushioned & secluded chairs.

Restaurant Molinais in Soho an Italian restaurant mostly show but good. Trianon, nothing particular.

Villa Villa 37 & 38 Gerrard St old home of Burke proprietors Peltamault & Zappeloni Dinner 3/6 wine 2/9 & coffee 6donce very notorious now rather on shabby side.

Cheshire Cheese in Fleet St with its old fashioned beams & special pie & Johnsons seats which you can occupy for a special sum.

Maxim. One of the nicest of restaurants built like Elysée (see pic}. The crowd is

very excited & commence by smiling at each other then throwing little bits of paper, then serviettes & even table cloths from each other & down to & up from the lower floor. Armistice does not come every day & they are making the most of it. Then floor is cleared & all done. The poor old head waiter is in a great funk & runs up to every one he sees throwing anything. I want to see night dances in London & head waiter finds a frenchman Meney of 6. Blandford House Frances St Tottenham Ct Road WC (phone 649 Museum) who took me round to Albert Rooms Whitford St where dancing is till 4 am, entrance£1 each. Women are mainly actresses & do not arrive till after 11. Men are nearly all officers from every race & quarter of the world. I have now become a nightbird staying out till 3 am every night soman hour later makes little difference. This cosmopolitan collection interested me muchly. Trocadero Bar a very small place. Bar here usually means a place where drinks are mixed not where they are consumed & so are usually small. Thus the greatest in London would be considered small in NSW.

Monea Bar, best about 8 pm, foreign element. Globe Theatre. Here Marie Lohr was playing Nurse Benson. She is not good though her reputation is great. She is to play Langdon but I do not fancy her in it. She is well supported.

London plays are as a rule exceptionally good & the same piece runs for years. Chu Chin Chow is now considerably over its 1000 nights. Picture shows are poor & many of the leading theatres would only be considered third rate with us. Nearly all the theatres are clustered in or about Shaftesbury Avenue. Imperial hotelin Russell Square is an old time hotelbut now much behind the times, largely patronised by Americans though whyI do not know as it is hopelessly out of

date no hot water in rooms - dirty walls & latrines. Berners Hotel in Berners St is very good but very quiet. The rooms contain easy chairs & ordinary chairs, washing stand, drawers, wardrobe. Carlton Hotel is about best in London occupies a square to itself. Bedrooms have telephone easy chairs is above with a bathroom & lavatory attached to room, costs 30/- per night, can ring Paris from your bed or any room in Hotel, service is good. Lounge is dwarfed by high roof. Meals cost about 15/- to 25/- though there is a limit on soldiers of
Entry.116:
Hence the inattention they often receive. Shaftesbury Hotel not bad interesting Murrays (under way) Regent St is theatrical club once but now admits any members. 400 Club & Caro are soon to open but not yet.

Manicure shops exist all over the place & are largely patronised by men. Nearly all shaving places keep a manicurist. Rogazski near Piccadilly Grill Rooms in Piccadilly all persons employed are women nice room with lounge & paper, writing desk, telephone & grate fire with easy chairs around it. 10 New Bond St is a manicure place only luxuriously fitted up Piccadilly Grill Room is a magnificent place with numbers of chandeliers & mirrors which reflected them & you seemed to be looking along an avenue of chandeliers.

At Imperial Hotel I met in the large lounge an officer in unknown uniform. Woollen tunic no belt collar edged with red piping. Blue epaulettes with stars. He is a Russian. Yarned till 1.30 am.

Burlington Arcade is a long arcade very narrow & more congested than ours. It has the appearance of a church aisle. The Art Gallery is worth the visit although all the old masters have not yet been put back. They were also taken into the basement for safety. The figures stand out from canvas quite naturally. Albert Moore's Blossoms a woman in pink



with a background of white flowers appealed to me more than any other perhaps because I know it best.
Entry.117:
This morning as I leave London Igo to see the upper reaches of the Thames. The best way to do this is to go to Reading (pron. Redding) & walk along tow path through Maidenhead to Windsor then train to Slough (19 M) & connect with main line. In train I met a French lady named Madame Paape of Taplow who told me that I might use her name with Mr Boss to get entréinto Cosmopolitan Club Rupert St. The Thames is pretty as no river I have seen before. The autumn leaves have not yet fallen & the colour of russet brown is glorious while a similar carpet is everywhere underfoot. looking up from the double bridges at Maidenhead scene is glorious. I lunched here at Skindles near Murrays. The banks are finally made up but covered with reeds to edge. One island has many houses on it but one can scarcely see them so dense is the vegetation. Houses are built on side with back waters running under them. One house called House on the creek is built across a creek & hemmed in with high hedges & trees. The bigger houses have lawns like green carpets running down to waters edge with shade trees & seats & stars of flowers in the lawn. One on an island was glorious, laid out with poplars planted regularly. At one bend a large building like a monastery rang its bell over a silent landside. The river on one side is flat meadow lands & on the other beech covered hill sometimes green with spruce & in other parts the autumn tinted brown. Rock & luxurious growth & growing right down to waters edge. I return to town & go to Berners Hotel Berners St near Oxford Circus. The hotel is quiet & the

room well fitted somewhat similar to Carlton but hot & cold water is not laid on nor telephone & only 1 electric light. As I had some difficulty on finding hotel I decided that it was too far away & would telephone RRC for another. Then I asked for telephone at Frascati & was misdirected. Then to find my way Iasked a man but could not understand him. Theydo not speak the English that I learnt in Australia. I thanked & asked next man who was a mute. At last I did find phone & discovered that the system was the same as Australia. In neither can you get your number but it costs 3dto get annoyed in England whereas in Australia it only costs 2d. I then went Cosmopolitan Club on Mde Pappe recommendation & had no difficulty in obtaining admission. The Jazz Band is here & I see a very clever exhibition of dancing by some of the coons. Here life is very Bohemian & after supper there is a dance at which everything is free & easy & every now & then some member will get up &give an exhibition which was well worth the visit. After leaving here I wander round the city again which is lively as on our first night. This afternoon the Americans who have done so little organised a big procession, & many other processions were formed including one by girl munition workers & WRAC's to Buckingham Palace. Yesterday I forgot to say I visited the Connaught Room of Kingsways & saw the Grand Lodge Rooms. A magnificent chamber massively decorated in gold with a faint light dimly lighting up the interior. Royal Arch is held in some rooms but there are only baout 5 other lodge rooms the temples being very numerous in London one at Frascati upstairs & one at Holborn Restaurant. The Monk Lodge has rooms in same building . I also visited Rose Croix in Dukes St. As to night is Saturday I think celebrations may culminate I decide to overstay leave especially as the medical authorities will never know the difference & it is not difficult to find a good excuse

during periods of armistice & this does not happen every day.
Entry.118:
This busy Sunday morning I go to Petticoat Lane a narrow street in the slum quarter which is used as a mart by the Jews on Sunday. Everything that you can name is sold here. There is nothing missed on which aJew can make a sale - even dead men's clothes are vended as such on one stall. The crowd is drawn there mostly by curiosity but they invariably fall to the wiles of some persevering Jew. It is just the same though not as crowded or so noisy as Chrisp St where in place of warehouse walls there are shops i e 4 rows of shops or stalls on a very narrow st. Leaving the East End I go to the West to Hyde Park & alight at Marble Arch. I then walk through the park which is just ordinary paddock with a fringe of leafless trees till I come to Rotten Row. Here the wealth of London passes its Sunday mornings torturing horses - a habit which the society of prevention of Cruelty to animals should intervene to stop. They are leased to call it riding. But as I said before I cannot speak the language of England riding must mean something different from our meaning. Then I visit the Lake - a big expanse of water very shallow, never more than 14 ft in which are several islands & which is crossed by a big solid stone bridge. I then try to catch the train & find the conveniences of the London Bus system. You signal driver to stop & he tries to pull up. Conductress does not see you & rings the bell & you are left. Next one is too crowded & wont stop & so on till you have missed the train. I had to go to Hotel to pack up overcoat & then to Tube which is some distance away. The hotel is not well situated. I just missed a tube & this makes me miss the train though I carry on hoping that there may be some fast trains which



will overtake it. But alas there is none & I have to wait till 7.35 pm as I have expended all my cash. I have
Entry.119: left so decide to go to Regent Palace Hotel & collect 11/00 which was owing to me through their system of deposit. Here I met an Aust officer & have morning tea with him & toss him to see who will pay. I win. I then have a good look round lounge which I hope never to see again & then set out for Jack Kennedy 4.30 near Radcliffe Gardens & met his wife & child. Instead of going to concert at Queens Hall as I intended I stay here & finally meet a mate Handerley Thursfield 9 Cathcart Rd South Kensington SW.10. & have afternoon tea at his place & finally catch train for Tedworth. In train are some English officers & when I ask if this train goes to Tedworth one a major replies in a tone which suggests I ought to address such questions to a porter. The English are truly a surly disagreeable nation & not merely conservative.
Entry.120: Went down & saw General McGlynn. He was affable & told me I was be in a week after I left here. Received a letter from Syd Uni Union re Xmas greetings. I was quite pleased but amused to find that it was Xmas 1917 & had been all this time reaching me . The address was
Entry.123:
Though only a few days out of hospital I decide to borrow a bike & go to the Forest of the Savernakea forest near Marlborough. it is a ride of 28 miles. The forest & the pond avenue the finest avenue in England consists of an avenue of beech trees 3 deep on each side of the path. The path with its carpet of leaves & overhead barren limbs & dales & hills is very pretty but not worth the effort to get there. On my return

darkness set in & I was put off the right road by the prevailing courtesy of English people who are either the greatest idiots on earth or people with a perverted sense of humour which delights in misleading strangers within the country. A more lying & deceitful race it is hard to find. They are so shameless. Owing to misdirection I had to walk last 6 miles. I was so tired that I could not sit on bicycle & had to ask some men to wheel the machine for me. The road is lonelier than Australian bush & as black as a pitch barrel. I went over the handle bars several times owing to running into side of road which I could not see. Once I landed on a hawthorn hedge & a lively & prickly seat it was. I tore my face, had gravel rash on my hands & cut my trousers. When I arrived at Barracks I had no tea owing to having to meet someone at 8.20 pm or 20-20 as they say here. Pearce & Smith were merry & insisted on riding the bike round the room & ended in a heap with tables, forms & bicycle in one big heap & the bike was damaged when it was returned. I was told I would not be allowed to have it again - at least I had some fun out of it.
Entry.125: Exams & loafing is order of the day mixed with wild rumours as to movements of Australians.
Entry.126: Though low in funds have decided to draw some money & go on leave Torquay & Bournemouth being my objectives. The control of a Bradshaw is an art& can only be acquired after years of experience. However as I was puzzling over it in the Club a pretty fair haired dolly faced wife of an officer came to my assistance & we worked out a time table an act of kindness as for few & far between with English people that I will always cherish its memory.
Entry.127:
Though leave commenced yesterday yet I did not start till this morning so that I could see the country through which I was passing. At station I met Dr Donlevy who is travelling as far as Bath. Change at Ludgershall then at Swindon & walk to Swindon Jn about½ hours walk & thence on to Bath. Country is same as elsewhere a succession of green fields with hedges around them, no sign of hills or forests. Arrived at Bath Donlevy escorts me as far as Wells (see booklet). after seeing these I went over the Abbey which is much the same as other abbeys although much worn by time. All the houses here are constructed of Bath stone & it does not stand the weather overmuch. I then walked the Roman promenade on the site of the old Roman walls. Many of the houses here bear plates stating that so & so lived here & the old dates. Lord Nelson once lived in a corner house & the tablet records this fact. Then I strolled to Museum which contains a good selection of relics taken from Barrows near by & one mummy of an Egyptian princess which is only about as tall as my breast pocket. I wondered if this is the normal size of the Egyptian of that day or whether it has shrunk. Met an Aust. officer & we paid a visit to Angel Hall. Bar is about 6 ft long capable of allowing 4 only to stand at it but rest of room has tables & chairs. In the train I find that owing to bad connections I have an hour to spend either at Exeter or Taunton & get out at Taunton with a naval officer I had met on the train. Taunton with its narrow streets is not very interesting save by its

history & the fact that hotels are open all day. Train stops at Newton Abbot & change for Torquay. I had been recommended to go to Victoria & Albert Hotel & on arrival found the hotel car waiting & before I knew where I was had arrived at Hotel just in time for dinner 7.15. Meal = soup, fish, a morsel of meat, dough (called pudding on menu) toast with a suspicion of cheese on it. Coffee is taken in the lounge where every one looks askance at you & make you feel like an intruder. It gets on my nerves & after smoking a cigarette go outside to find a cinema or theatre. Finally find Electric (pronounced Lattrick) Theatre. Then I wander round the town along Union St into Belgrade St & then to bed.
Entry.128:
Sunday
There are no trains in the village till 2 pm on Sunday which is rather difficult for sight seeing. However the restriction of petrol has been lifted for day &cars can go within a 30 miles radius. I walk down Belgrave St to Promenade where a fine view of the three hills with clear rows of white houses rising in tiers one above the other. These three hills comprise the city. Road leads past Princess Pier the land south basin or Harbour on the edge of the firstthere is a neat little garden. Further on there is the town & a naval aerodrome & then road seems to lead away from coast so I take what seems to me to be the natural turning & find myself walking along past Imperial Hotel & little secluded bays but road finally ends in a track leading to natural arch which I try to scale but am too weak & soil too greasy so retrace my steps. Road is now on series of full coastal views though there are no real cliffs & the rocks seem a kind

of clay or rather the rock decomposes readily into clay. Beaches of sand do not exist but here & there one can find a shingle beach. The bays are at first small & cosy but after passing Hydro & Osborne Hotel it lengthens. The view from a lookout near Hydro is fine. The shingle beach being many hundreds of feet below. Continuing walk leads on to Babbacombe a pretty little spot which is reached by travelling up a gully. here I cut across private grounds much to amazement of chap I had asked for way & find myself on Lincombe Drive which is a drive around the top of the cliffs which here rise to a great height. One view above gully is exceptionally beautiful being a saddle between two near hills clothed with trees & grass on which sheep feed & everywhere the eternal hedges cutting across it. The drive winds in & out among trees some of whose branches are dressed in ivy & now & again receding as some valley cuts into hills. It is a pretty trip. I leave Drive near Manor House & wander among the Manor Gardens. The climate here is a little tropical & all the trees & bushes are evergreens. The Garden consists of snug bower& little winding path with trees meeting just a few feet over one's head. From here continuing a walk round the tops of cliff I enter rock walk (after climbing many steps) & thence into Carey Gardens & home. The road or path here often for great distances run between rock walls each about 6 ft high. These so obtrude themselves that one has the idea of going through a prison rather than a seaside walk. In afternoon I took the train to Paynton, visited Cockingham, & thence on to Totnes. Just before reachingTotnes near 3 M past a magnificent view is obtained looking across to the Dartmoor Hills. The whole countryside is very hilly with deep ravines. The hills are covered with trees. This is certainly the

prettiest country in Eng. The roads are always sunken being walled up to 6 to 8 ft or else & then as more usual a bank 4 to 5 ft & on top a hedge. With beech trees on each side & meeting overhead. From Totnes road stretches on to Kingswear & across the River Dart is Dartmouth with its great naval college. The day is foggy & covered darkness 5 pm obscures everything. The soil is red & thoughts of "Red Devon by the Sea". At hotel girls waiters are liveried rather strange to see a girl all big buttons. Women here wear furs & hats to Lunch perhaps for fear of losing them. Old women here in great numbers & conversation between them is very banal. Some seem to drink wine because it is fashionable know as etiquette & empty bottle by turning it perpendicularly upside down irrespective of sediment. It seems to be object fullest quantity for money invested & this is not Brighton where Jews predominate. After dinner I yarn with an old lady & her husband who have spent many years here& were very interesting. Then hunted up Bradshaw.
Entry.129:
I find that to get to Bournemouth I must start earlier than I expected. Train leaves at 9. I manage to scramble an early breakfast & get a few post cards at the station. Train passes up to Newton Abbot & then skirts the very beaches almost till we reach river Exe an apology for a river being a little water moving over mud banks. The cliffs are a red soil rather than rock. Though the views are softer than our coastline yet it is more barren. On arrival at Exeter where I change I get out at St David's station & find that the connecting train leaves from another station Queens about 1 mile away & that it left "5 minutes" before I arrived. Hence I did not make the connection & found myself in Exeter with 4 hours

on my hands. I visit the walls & see towers of Rochester Castle & gaze across countryside from its walls. A magnificent view with the River Exe & Exmouth in the distance. Below the castle are the beautiful Rougement Gardens while on the outside run the old city walls with the precipitous approaches, walls which enabled Exeter to gain its title of the "ever faithful city" & which now form a promenade. Then to Cathedral much worn with age but with its still beautiful carvings on west fronts. The inside is spoiled by the position of its organ while in nave is a grand old two faced clock which also day of month. Then I slip into a room with Elizabethan panelling just as it was when the naval military leaders who fought the Armada met in it in 1588. Further on I find the Guildhall which was built in 1300 or thereabouts with its numerous panels on it each guild & everyone different. It is now used as a municipal meeting place & a Court of Assize. Near by is an old carving of St Peter (?) trampling on the dragon for which there is a trust - producing£25 per annum for its upkeep. Then I visit Museum with a wonderful collection of lower forms of sea life. Here I met a Canadian officer who was opening a collection of Canadian war pictures & allowed me to look through though not officially opened. Incidentally he recommended me to go to Rougement Hotel for lunch where I again saw him. I catch train at 2.10 & after many changes & a long wait at Templecombe a small insignificant town arrive at Bournemouth West. There are two Bournemouths & I did not know for which I was making but meeting an officer in train he put me on to Imperial Hotel & accompanied me to it. Hotel is very comfortable with a mass of statuary in every corner & its frescoed or painted walls & painted ceilings. Seats & lounges exist on every landing & along all the halls. At dinner I met an interesting

companion who chatted with me in the smoke room & into our conversation a third person joined who is I understand Solomons President of R.A. recently camouflage, artist to British army Tanks. Conversation is very interesting.
Entry.130:
As I have lost a day through missing trains I must hurry to make most of my time here. So I go out before breakfast along towards Beach. The avenue or streets here are pretty. Scotch firs & evergreens abound & on each side of streets are narrow plantations while at cross roads a little green rotunda. The cliff is not rock but soil clay with rounded quartz. A zigzag leads down & there is a lift electric worked on counterpoise systems. Along beach at bottom of cliff runs a wide asphalted promenade. Beach varies in depth from a few feet to 200 yds near pier. Pier is a cuddling resort on which band plays during certain hours. The end is suitable for dancing & numerous panes of glass give protection fromwind. Opposite to pier are the Winter Gardens with the or Pine Walk. Through the centre runs a stream which could have been made artistically beautiful with a very little effort but is just a bare drain. After breakfast I walked along drive on on top of cliffs to Bournemouth & up through Boscombe then to train whence I went to Southbourne & to Hengistbury Head whence a good view of Isle of Wight & the Needles the nearest point can be obtained. Then I took train to Christchurch. Fare here was very dear even as compared with rest of England & all trains are doubledeckers & awfully slow. One can walk as fast as trains. Their speed rarely exceeds 8 miles per hour & their halts are excessively long.

I return viaBrescombe a thickly wooded little ravine with path at the bottom & a large pool for children half way down. Then along beach. Hundreds of Bath cars drawn by little shetland ponies & occupied by stout elderly ladies promenade for the fresh air. Along beaches are little cubicles which would be blown away with first decent wind or washed away if sea became rough. The cliffs are now rock & if grass or something steps be not taken to preserve it crumbling away there will soon be no cliffs. In afternoon I paid a visit to other side (Poole). Walked along cliffs & across Durley Canalthen Middle Canal& then up Alan Canalwhich is spanned by two bridges & is the prettiest of the three. Then to Rly Station & booked ticket then to Nobbys for afternoon tea & then to metropole whence I went to Station & had a long argument in train with an English barrister re merits of English race. Arrived in camp finally & found all in confusion but managed to find a home.
Entry.131: Dettman had arranged to bring my luggage down for me & leave it in his room. I get them down & find contents of trunk has been rifled to extent of£10 or more including my service revolver. I report matter & ask for a search. This is done & man Fisher is leaving for Australia & revolver is found but nothing else. Have rested all day in room writing up diary.
Entry.132: Dodge parade all day or else walked around & looked intelligent. No one worries now as war is finished & all interest is gone.
Entry.133: A concert party called the Scots arrived & after concert came to mess. I discovered a brother Mason & a little Irish French girl called Barrie. As some officers had left for Australia that day it was very wet in the mess & everyone happy. Party is farewelled about 2 am with fusillade of Very lights. Then Cox & I adjourn to kitchen & make ourselves many slices of toast & dripping & then at 3 am try to carry my room mate out & put him among the cabbages.
Entry.134:
Sat.
Go to Salisbury. Lucky enough to catch a special train after waiting 2¼ hrs for a car which we had ordered early in the day. I had wired someone to meet me at Leatherhead & although she must have had 3 hours notice she did not turn up so I visited Cathedral an airy edifice building all in one style & as per post cards. Then we rambled through Salisbury - visited an hotel built in 1100 called the Haunch of Venison & another The sign of the George built in 1329 & now dry. Spent some time at Crown Hotel & dined at Bluebird. Here you can only buy one glass of whiskey in each hotel & you walk to the next hotel for the next drink. Rather expensive on shoe leather. The hotels are nearly all very old.buildings. We came home by train which carries no lights in same carriage as two nursing sisters.
Entry.135:
This afternoon Eade & I went for a long walk 14 miles to see an old ruined castle called Wardour which with 30 men held 1200 at bay for 5 days under the lady of the house Blanche Arundell & was afterward besieged by the owner & blown in pieces. The situation is in a narrow gully & not on a wood hill top as one would suppose. The lands approaching glade are filled with trees as large as I have ever seen in England & has a hill on one hand & river bed on other. Scotch fir &


spruce lend funereal or ghostly air to place. The Castle has a lake at foot & raised walk. Plan . The approach is about 1½ miles & the spot is idyllic. The trees are evergreen & the lawn & fount within the walls look even now like a painting. This quiet & secluded spot is rich with charms & a beauty that still lingers on in spite of Ruins touch. The Castle possessed 4 stories & a dungeon floor. The dining hall was about 12 ft above ground level & entered from a door on right of courtyard up a winding staircase. Reluctantly we entered this scene of desolation & one time loyalty. Arrived home too late for dinner but had a heavy supper & Richards 32.
Entry.137:
Tues
Usual loafing & fooling around. Camp was to have been moved to Codford No 6 Camp Wednesday now it is Friday & at present Saturday.
Entry.138:
Wed
This morning worked at loading lorries for shift & finished at 11 am & dismissed me on my own responsibility to cover. This afternoon all that is left of company is 10 men & 3 officers. Betts goes off & Eade & I take these 10 men & lose them on hill giving them instructions to walk back to camp at dismissal time & we inspected Chiselbury Camp a raised circular mound with a light ditch perhaps 6 ft deep. Then we walked over to Broad Chalke an old rural village.
